Research Carbohydrate Staple Food Modulates Gut Microbiota of Mongolians in China Li Jing Hou Qiangchuan Zhang Jiachao Xu Haiyan Sun Zhihong Menghe Bilige Zhang Heping Key Laboratory of Dairy Biotechnology and Engineering Education Ministry of P R China Department of Food Science and Engineering Inner Mongolia Agricultural University Hohhot China Edited by Zhongtang Yu Ohio State University at Columbus USA Reviewed by Francisco Javier University of Jeffrey David Galley Baylor College of Medicine USA Bilige Menghe com Heping Zhang sina com These authors have contributed equally terms Gut microbiota is a determining factor in human physiological functions and health It is commonly accepted that diet has a major influence on the gut microbial community however the effects of diet is not fully understood The typical Mongolian diet is characterized by high and frequent consumption of fermented dairy products and red meat and low level of carbohydrates In this study the gut microbiota profile of Mongolians whom consumed wheat rice and oat as the sole carbohydrate staple food for a week each consecutively was determined It was observed that changes in staple carbohydrate rapidly a altered gut microbial community structure and metabolic pathway of the subjects Wheat and oat favored bifidobacteria Bifidobacterium catenulatum Bifodobacteriumbifidum Bifidobacterium adolescentis whereas rice suppressed bifidobacteria Bifidobacterium longum Bifidobacterium adolescentis and wheat suppresses Lactobaciilus Ruminococcus and Bacteroides The study exhibited two gut microbial clustering patterns with the preference of fucosyllactose utilization linking to fucosidase genes hydrolase family classifications and encoded by Bifidobacterium and xylan and arabinoxylan utilization linking to xylanase and arabinoxylanase genes encoded by Bacteroides There was also a correlation between Lactobacillus ruminis and sialidase as well as Butyrivibrio crossotus and xylanase xylosidase Meanwhile a strong concordance was found between the gastrointestinal bacterial microbiome and the intestinal virome Present research will contribute to understanding the impacts of the dietary carbohydrate on human gut microbiome which will ultimately help understand relationships between dietary factor microbial populations and the health of global humans intestinal microbiome carbohydrateutilization Mongolians staple food Introduction The assessment of microbial communities in human feces has uncovered a large quantity and types of microbial species colonizing the human gut A growing body of research has indicated that the microbial communities are associated with the digestion of dietary macronutrients production of nutrients and vitamins and maintenance of the host immunity Thus the gastrointestinal microbiota can be considered a highly active metabolic organ to complement the human metabolic activities Wu et al found that two enterotypes Prevotella community and Bacteroides were defined among human communities in different geographical regions The Prevotella community and the Bacteroides community were associated with fiber intake and high protein intake respectively The dietary fibers proteins and peptides which escape digestion by host enzymes in the upper gut are metabolized by the microbiota in the colon thus determine the microbiota in the lower reach of the gut and feces Macfarlane and Macfarlane The metabolites such as fatty acids that are produced by gut bacterial fermentation are available to the hostenterocytes and can influence host physiological processes The balance of the gut microbial community is a major determining factor in human physiological functions Many reports have demonstrated determining factors of the gut microbial community these includehost genotype diet age disease and use of antibiotic Yatsunenko et al It is commonly accepted that diet has a major influence on the gut microbial community The structure of the gut microbial community can be changed by consumption of a habitual diet Ley et al Walker et al Wu et al as well as consumption of certain diets David et al Dietary alteration in the gut microbiota profile could be temporal David et al or irreversible Sonnenburg et al In China the dietary habit is significantly different from the western diets Chinese diet revolves around a diet such as cereal vegetable and fruit supplemented with protein such as dairy products seafood and meat The grain rice and naked is generally called staple food and accounts for a high proportion of the daily diet In different areas of China people have different dietary habit the general staple food for people living south of Yangtze River is rice Oryza sativa var in the area north of the Yangtze River people subsist chiefly on wheat Triticum spp whereas people in the north of the Yellow River one of the major staple food is naked oats Avena sativa The wheat rice and naked oats contain different content of carbohydrates starch polysaccharides and For example the wheat contains about of carbohydrates mainly as xylose and arabinose the naked oats contain of arabinose and whereas rice contains carbohydrate Bednar et al The different grain intake may have an influence on the gut microbiota A diet intervention study based on administration of showed changes in the gut microbial composition De Angelis et al The effects of carbohydrate staple diet on the gut microbial community have been little studied A recent study comparing fecal microbiota profile of central Asian and and Southeast Asia and speculated that carbohydrates and meat consumption are determining dietary factors in the Bacteroides Nakayama et al It is the aim of this study to investigate the effect of the three staple food grains on the gut microbial communities via diet intervention The typical Mongolian diet is characterized by a high and frequent consumption of fermented dairy products and red meat and a low level of the grain intake The result of the diet intervention based on the type of carbohydrates for Mongolian may be more obvious than that of the Chinese In our previous study Bull by using the PacBio single molecule sequencing technology we revealed the changes in intestinal microbiota of Mongolian volunteers based on rRNA variable regions response to staple carbohydrate The intestinal microbiome was composed of the microbial taxonomy microbial function and metabolic pathway So previous research only focused on the microbial taxonomic level meet our further understanding of the interaction between the intestinal microbiome and diet Accordingly in present research the shotgun metagenomic sequencing approach was applied to generate huge sequencing reads of microbial whole genomes Following procedure analysis involving assembling gene prediction and pathway annotation enabled us to pay more attention to changes in intestinal microbial functional genes and metabolic pathways Meanwhile a robust network based on species metabolic pathway and food nutrition was constructed for helping us understanding the impacts of the dietary carbohydrate on human gut microbiome which will ultimately help understand relationships between dietary factor microbial populations and the health of global humans Materials and Methods Study Design and Sample Collection In present research Mongolian subjects years started the experiments on day upon arrival in China All subjects had no gastrointestinal disorder and did not take any antibiotics for three months before the experiment started and until the end of the experiment During the experiment dietary staple food was replaced each week first week wheat the second week rice and third week and the amount and species of food intake for each individual was the same every day The information was shown in the Supplementary Table And the diet was prepared by a restaurant according to the designed recipes All volunteers were instructed to eat only the provided foods or allowable beverages or unsweetened They also confirmed that no remarkable changes occurred in their diet intake and no medication was taken during the experiment The fecal samples of each individual in time points week to week were collected for further sequencing The study protocol was approved by the Ethical Committee of the Inner Mongolia Agriculture University Sampling and all subsequent steps described in the Materials and Methods have been conducted in accordance with the approved guidelines After obtaining the written informed consent we collected habitual dietary information from all participants using a food frequency questionnaire Table All subjects gave written informed consent in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki Metagenomic DNA Extraction The QIAamp DNA Stool Mini Kit Hilden was used for DNA extraction from the fecal samples The quality of the metagenomic DNA was assessed by agarose gel electrophoresis All of the DNA samples were stored at until further processing Shotgun Metagenomic Sequencing and Quality Control The Illumina platform was used for shotgun metagenomic sequencing reads were generated with bp in the forward and reverse directions The length of each read was trimmed with Sickle This set of reads was then used for a further analysis An average of gigabases of reads were obtained for each sample totalling more than Tb of data free of host genomic and adaptor contaminants Shotgun Metagenomic Reads De novo Assembly Gene Prediction and Construction of the Gene Catalog The Illumina reads were assembled into contigs using Peng et al with default parameters Genes were predicted on the contigs with MetaGeneMark Zhu et al A gene catalog was constructed with Li and Godzik using a sequence identity of with a minimum coverage of for the shorter sequences This catalog contained microbial genes Computation of Relative Gene Abundance To assess the abundance of genes profile reads were aligned to the gene catalog with Langmead et al using the following parameters nt fastq fastq R sam Then for any sample N we calculated the abundance as follows Step Calculation of the copy number of each gene b i x i L i Step Calculation of the relative abundance of gene i a i b i i b i ai the relative abundance of gene i bi the copy number of gene i from sample N Li the length of gene i xi the number of mapped reads Construction of the Taxonomic Profiling We use Segata et al to produce organism abundance profiling with default parameters which relied on about million unique marker genes identified from about reference genomes Meanwhile the metagenomic reads were annotated by the NCBI virus database to build the virome profile Annotation of KEGG CAZy and ARGs Database We aligned the amino acid sequences that were translated from the gene catalog against the proteins domains to the Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes and antibiotic resistance genes databases using BLASTP e with a higher than Each protein was assigned to the KEGG ortholog group or ARG number by the highest scoring annotated hit CAZymes were predicted from amino acid sequences by against to HMM of CAZymes in dbCAN database Yin et al using Hmmscan program in HMMER package Eddy KEGG Pathway Analysis Differentially enriched KO modules and pathways were identified according to the reporterscores Patil and Nielsen from the Z of individual KOs Accordingly the Z adjusted pathway of each KEGG module and pathway was calculated as previously described Patil and Nielsen Then the Z adjusted pathway was used as the final reporter score for evaluating the enrichment of specific pathways or modules A reporter score of confidence according to the normal could be used as a detection threshold for significantly differentiating pathways Statistical Analysis All statistical analyses were undertaken using the R software PCoA and a kernel density distribution analysis were performed using the Zapala and Schork package of R software Differential abundance of species genes and KOs were tested by the Wilcoxon rank sum test and the significantly different p The heatmap was built in R using the package The correlation between the dietary components metabolic pathways and relative genera were calculated by rank correlation coefficient and visualized by network in Cytoscape Accession Numbers The sequence data reported in this paper have been deposited in the NCBI database data Results Dynamic Profile of Gut Microbiome in Response to Changes in Staple genes was constructed Annotated by HMP database thus taxonomy profile of each sample was obtained Meanwhile the reads were mapped to the collective gene catalog to reconstruct gene profile as well as the profiles for the associated KEGG database Orthologs Supplementary Table At the taxonomy level Principal Coordinates Analysis was performed based on the unweighted UniFrac Figure weighted UniFrac comparing the first principal component of distance matrices representing taxonomic and functional features in gut community structure among subjects at each time point we found that changed staple organismal profile and that of genus level phage profile Figure The results revealed a strong correspondence between the two profiles above P using Monte Carlo label which also indicated a potential synergistic interaction between the bacteria and bacterial virus in human gastrointestinal tract The Functional Specificity of Intestinal Microbiota for Carbohydrate Utilization As the main component of the staple food in the present study was carbohydrate we focused on the functional specificity of intestinal microbiota for carbohydrate utilization The gene catalog in our study was annotated by enzymes database and a total of carbohydrate metabolism related enzymes were identified Table By applying the test we observed significant difference in enzymes among the different staple food groups and these enzymes were mainly related to the metabolism of glucose Figure Meanwhile by clustering analysis we exhibited the correlation profile between the microbial species and the enzymes Figure and two apparent clustering patterns could be found in the profile which indicated two groups of intestinal microbiota with preference for specific carbohydrates utilization Accordingly we reconstruct the network between the species and their metabolic enzymes for each group Figure The first group including the species of Alistipe sputredinis Bacteroides intestinalis Bacteroides massiliensis Bacteroides plebeius Bacteroides salyersiae Bacteroides vulgutas Bacteroides uniformis Butyrivibrio crossotus Megaspha eraelsdenii Parabacteroides merdae and Paraprevotella clara and they were closely related to the enzymes of arabinofuranosidase pectin lyase polygalacturonaseand xylanase The second group including the species of Alistipesonderdonkii Bacteroides fragilis Bifidobacterium adolescentis Bifidobacterium breve Bifidobacterium pseudocatenulatum Lactobacillus ruminis Ruminococcus gnavus and Streptococcus thermophilus and they were closely related to the enzymes of mannosidase trehalose phosphorylase fucosidase and sialidase FIGURE The specificity of intestinal microbiota for carbohydrate utilizing The first species network group were closely related to the enzymes of arabinofuranosidase pectin lyase polygalacturonase and xylanase The second species network group were closely related to the enzymes of mannosidase trehalose phosphorylase fucosidase and sialidase The Linear Relationship between Intestinal Microbial Phylum and Main Nutrient Elements The results above based on the impacts of changes in staple food on intestinal microbiome offered us an excellent opportunity to reveal the linear relationship between intestinal microbial phylum and main nutrient elements which was also the basic mechanism related to the interaction between the diet and gut microbiome According to the fitted curves we observed a declined in phylum Actinobacteria but an increase in phylum Firmicutes with the gradually increasing carbohydrates content in diet Figure At the same time the phylum Bacteroidetes and Proteobacteria presented a positive correlation with the dietary fat and digestible carbohydrate respectively Figure FIGURE The linear relationship between intestinal microbial phylum and main nutrient elements The relationship among the intestinal microbiota dietary nutrition and ARGs The Relationship between Intestinal Microbiota Dietary Nutrition and ARGs To further understand the dietary effects on human microbiome we annotated our gene catalog with the ARGs database and constructed the ARGs profile of each individuals By merging and classifying annotated ARGs were clustered into antibiotic catalog Table We found that the ARGs related to vancomycin were most abundant followed by the ARGs related to macrolide tetracycline bacitracin tigecycline penicillin chloramphenicol lincosamide and aminoglycoside which gene abundance were more than To describe the relationship among the dietary nutrition microbial phylum and ARGs above a Circos on line diagram was constructed Figure Discussion By employing the shotgun metagenomic sequencing we described the dynamic profile of gut microbiome in response to changes in staple food The composition of the gut microbiome can be considered as a complex trait with the quantitative variation in the microbiome affected by a large number of host and environmental factors each of which may have only a small additive effect making it difficult to identify the association for each separate item A research study of participants from a Dutch cohort showed relations between the microbiome and exogenous and intrinsic host factors including intrinsic factors diseases drug groups smoking categories and dietary factors Zhernakova et al They observed that fecal chromogranin A a protein secreted by enteroendocrine cells was exclusively associated with microbial species whose abundance collectively accounted for of microbial composition Even so the diet and the genotype were also considered as the main force for shaping human intestinal microbiome although it remains unclear if this is primarily driven by host genetics or by extrinsic factors like dietary intake To address this another recent study Carmody et al examined the effect of dietary perturbations on the gut microbiota of five inbred mouse strains and revealed the consumption of a diet reproducibly altered the gut microbiota despite differences in host genotype Repeated dietary shifts demonstrated that most changes to the gut microbiota are reversible which emphasize diet dominates host genotype in shaping the murine gut microbiota Nevertheless in the present study we observed the staple change was much smaller than the difference which indicated the complexity of the interaction between the baseline microbiota and diet change Besides we also found that changes in staple food rapidly altered microbial community structure and metabolic pathway for each individual Recent research also confirmed gut microbiome can rapidly respond to altered diet within day David et al and an diet had a greater effect on the microbiota than a diet In our previous study the effect of gut microbiota communities by the diet intervention of meals composed principally of wheat rice and oats was investigated by the PacBio single molecule sequencing technology based on rRNA variable region During the diet switch within a period the bacterial richness and diversity decreased apparently along the diet intervention And the structure of gut microbiota communities after the diet switch was found to be different from those before the diet switch The previous research only focused on the changes in the microbial taxonomic level but the intestinal microbiome including the microbial taxonomy and microbial function and metabolic pathway Accordingly in present research we pay more attention to the changes in intestinal microbial functional genes and metabolic pathways response to staple carbohydrate To probe for the potential metabolic mechanism underlying the dominant species Bacteroides ovatus Faecalibacterium prausnitzii Lactobacillus ruminis Bacteroides stercoris an Phascolarctobacterium succinatutens which thrive in the gut environment we analyzed the functional features in these bacteria and revealed that these microbes were enriched in the metabolic pathway of PTS PTS is an active sugar uptake method in low nutrient environment The bacterial PTS is a perfect example of both the opportunistic nature of bacterial life and their thrifty use of resources In the present study the of the metabolic pathway of phosphotransferase efficiently provide the source of energy for the species involved so that they can effectively and stably proliferated in human gut The human enteric microbiome contains viruses bacteria archaea fungi and other eukaryotic organisms Norman et al Virgin Enteric human virome and bacterial microbiome alterations have been linked to inflammatory bowel disease obesity and changes in host behavior Backhed et al Lyte Norman et al In the present study we observed a robust synergistic interaction between the bacteria and bacterial virus in human gastrointestinal tract in dynamic equilibrium with all components of the microbiome Accordingly an emerging concept is that the virome may contain mutualistic symbiotes with some effects that benefit the host and others by modulating the population of their bacterial host Bacteriophages regulate the bacterial microbiome via gene transfer killing competing bacteria to allow invasion of bacteria to fill a partly emptied niche or by encoding toxins that alter the host intestine to foster bacterial pathogenesis Duerkop and Hooper The ability to utilize complex dietary and host glycans is central to the survival of prominent members of the gut microbiota Plants in the form of fruits vegetables and cereals are major components of the human diet El Kaoutari et al They provide carbohydrates that are readily digested by human intestinal enzymes as well as dietary fibers which are resistant to digestion and absorption in the human small intestine enzymes encoded by the human gut microbiome catalyze the breakdown of glycoconjugates oligosaccharides and polysaccharides to fermentable monosaccharides El Kaoutari et al Here we exhibited two apparent gut microbial clustering patterns with the preference of specific carbohydrates utilization For instance the fucosyllactose utilization was linked tofucosidase genes hydrolase family classifications and encoded by Bifidobacterium Milani et al and the xylan and arabinoxylan utilization was linked to xylanase and arabinoxylanase genesencoded by Bacteroides Wu et al Furthermore we revealed the robust correlation between the Lactobacillus ruminis and sialidase as well as the Butyrivibriocrossotus and xylanase xylosidase These findings allow modeling of human gut microbiome responding to diet change and prebiotics for precision microbiota manipulation In summary this study describes the dynamic profile of gut microbiome in Mongolians in response to changes in staple food wheat rice and oat as the sole for weeks and revealed the impact of wheat on intestinal microbiota was the largest followed by rice and oat Accordingly we exhibited the specificity of intestinal microbiota for carbohydrate utilizing and the linear relationship between intestinal microbiota and major nutrient elements Meanwhile a strong concordance was found between the gastrointestinal bacterial microbiome and the intestinal virome Present research will contribute to understanding the impacts of the dietary carbohydrate on human gut microbiome which will ultimately help understand relationships between dietary factor microbial populations and the health of global humans Author Contributions HZ and BM designed the study JL and HX collected samples HX and ZS processed and sequenced samples JZ QH and ZS accepted academic practice No use distribution or reproduction is permitted which does not comply with these terms Objective Motor evoked potentials obtained by transcranial magnetic stimulation enable measures of the corticospinal excitability However the reliability of CSE measures is suboptimal due to appreciable MEP amplitude variability We thus calculated how many MEPs will be needed to obtain a reliable CSE measure in awake adult subjects in the eyes open and eyes closed conditions Methods Twenty healthy adults received consecutive navigated TMS pulses resting motor threshold in the EO or EC conditions on two separate days in randomized order Results For either the EO or EC condition the probability that the confidence interval derived from consecutive MEP amplitude measured included the true CSE increased when the number of consecutive stimuli increased p EC p No significant effect of RMT State Examination score or gender on the CSE estimates was identified At least consecutive stimuli were required to obtain a most reliable CSE estimate in the EO condition and in the EC condition Conclusion Our findings indicate that consecutive MEPs may be necessary in order to obtain a CSE measure in healthy adults motor evoked potential electromyography muscles transcranial magnetic stimulation Introduction Transcranial magnetic stimulation is a painless and safe method for focal cortical stimulation induced by generating magnetic field by passing a brief intracranial electrical current through a magnetic coil et al Kobayashi and When applied to the primary motor cortex and coupled with hand surface electromyography TMS is often used to measure corticospinal excitability as reflected in the amplitude or area under the curve of a hand muscle motor evoked potential CSE is generally equated to the average MEP amplitude resulting from multiple stimuli to the same region at identical intensities et al Magistris et al et al Pitcher et al Darling et al Mars et al Bashir et al Roy Choudhury et al Lewis et al Cakar et al Yet MEP amplitudes vary considerably from pulse to pulse in individual subjects et al et al Pitcher et al Roy Choudhury et al and this leads to compromising reliability of CSE metrics In most protocols MEPs are averaged for the CSE estimate et al et al Pitcher et al Bashir et al Roy Choudhury et al Lewis et al Yet number of TMS pulses and MEPs that are necessary to obtain a reliable CSE estimate is unknown We therefore stimulated the motor cortex in healthy volunteers and measured the number of intrinsic hand muscle MEP amplitudes that would be needed to obtain a reliable CSE estimate Since the instantaneous state of cortical motor neuron and cortical interneuron activity likely plays a role in MEP amplitude variability in TMS experiments we obtained these measures in two conditions awake with eyes open and eyes closed which previously have been demonstrated to modulate cortical and or spinal motoneural output et al In the present experiment we hypothesized to test whether the number of pulses needed to establish a CSE metric from the first dorsal interosseous muscle representation is mediated by factor for which studies may not reliably control activation of the visual system as defined by the EO and EC condition Materials and Methods Subjects Twenty control subjects participated in this study The Edinburgh Handedness Inventory Oldfield was administered to verify that all subjects were The participants had normal cognitive scores range as indexed by State Examination Folstein et al suggest any underlying neurological or psychological condition The investigation was carried out in accordance with the latest version of the Declaration of Helsinki and was approved by the local required as a function of the probability of hitting the confidence interval for EC Discussion We demonstrate that stimuli are required to obtain an accurate CSE estimate when MEP measures are obtained from the FDI muscle in healthy adults Notably this measure is independent of RMT and gender This basic practical information might play a crucial role for obtaining a reliable CSE in the TMS experiments This study showed the reliability as every part of the data were collected by the same rater The interpretation of our results about CSE estimates by number of consecutive stimuli might be required different for other age groups and in disease populations because our data was obtained in healthy young subjects Second all subjects were informed with respect to the experimental procedures due to uncertainty about their first TMS which likely caused changes in attention and this variable may differ from study to study Furthermore experimental TMS different coil types and EMG hardware and signal analysis for noise elimination can affect variability and reliability of the CSE measurements Last our measures were obtained from the CI muscle and a different numerical result may be seen in other muscle groups It is paramount that any reliability studies such as ours clearly outline the extent to which its results can be generalized We thus proposed to extrapolate from our results with qualification Reliability and reproducibility of protocol depends on the sample the paradigm the TMS setup and the operator et al The variability related to the TMS method should be similar across the laboratories when one considers that we used stimulator and recording devices that is commonly available This is the first TMS reliability study showing spatial stimulation stability within and between sessions using neuronavigation et al It is noteworthy to emphasize that the lack of controlling in pitch and roll of TMS coil just by using marked scalps or swimming caps can cause measurement error as it allows spatial drift et al and reduces the constancy and strength of intracranial electrical currents conveyed to a target et al The design of TMS experiments can be improved Front Genet Front Genet Frontiers in Genetics Frontiers Media S A fgene Genetics Mini Review Unveiling the Impact of the Genomic Architecture on the Evolution of Vertebrate microRNAs Gustavo S Hinske Ludwig C Galante Pedro A F Vibranovski Maria D Departamento de e Biologia Evolutiva Universidade de Paulo Paulo Brazil Department of Anesthesiology Clinic of the University of Munich Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich Munich Germany Centro de Oncologia Molecular Hospital Paulo Brazil Edited by Scott V Edwards Harvard University USA Reviewed by Antonio Marco University of Essex Bastian Fromm Oslo University Hospital Danillo Pinhal Paulo State University Brazil Gustavo S gustavo org Maria D Vibranovski usp br Present address Gustavo S Institute for Computational Medicine NYU School of Medicine East Street New York NY USA This article was submitted to Evolutionary and Population Genetics a section of the journal Frontiers in Genetics Copyright Hinske Galante and Vibranovski Hinske Galante and Vibranovski This is an article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License The use distribution or reproduction in other forums is permitted provided the original or licensor are credited and that the original publication in this journal is cited in accordance with accepted academic practice No use distribution or reproduction is permitted which does not comply with these terms Eukaryotic genomes frequently exhibit interdependency between transcriptional units as evidenced by regions of high gene density It is well recognized that vertebrate microRNAs are usually embedded in those regions Recent work has shown that the genomic context is of utmost importance to determine miRNA expression in time and space thus affecting their evolutionary fates over long and short terms Consequently understanding the and intraspecific changes on miRNA genomic architecture may bring novel insights on the basic cellular processes regulated by miRNAs as well as phenotypic evolution and mechanisms intragenic intergenic region new and old miRNAs host gene target interactions expression breadth Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento e de Amparo Pesquisa do Estado de Paulo Introduction Recent projects have revealed an outstanding transcriptome diversity especially of RNAs as well as a wealth of regulatory mechanisms and gene product interactions that compound the molecular basis of phenotypes Carninci et al Mele et al A notable feature that soon became clear is the interleaved nature of eukaryotic genomes despite their typical large sizes This means that a particular genomic region can be suited for different purposes with an extensive overlap of transcriptional units either in sense or antisense DNA strands Kapranov et al The interleaved model opens up numerous possibilities for regulatory mechanisms For instance products of antisense transcription which is believed to occur in more than of gene loci in humans Galante et al can regulate gene activity through many different ways in Pelechano and Steinmetz In the interleaved genome transcription units may show high interdependency whereby neighboring or overlapping genes can be by shared regulatory yet structural changes in the chromatin environment can also influence their expression coordinately Mellor et al Complex transcriptional networks thus emerge from a modular architecture that can either be shaped by evolutionary advantages and constraints Mercer and Mattick but also as a result of neutral processes Graur et al Such interleaved architecture is particularly striking in regard to microRNAs Ever since the first studies on their genomic organization Rodriguez et al it is commonly observed that these small RNAs overlap to genes with vertebrate miRNAs mapping to intronic regions more than expected by chance Baskerville and Bartel Hinske et al et al Meunier et al As they comprise an essential class of gene expression regulators in basic biological processes and diseases genomic context analyses are pivotal to uncover unique aspects of miRNA biology Here we discuss recent advances in this topic focusing on the importance of the genomic context to miRNA expression and their target interactions In this framework we highlight the evolutionary consequences for the fixation of newly emerged miRNAs and functional properties arising from context relationships over terms The Impact of the Genomic Context on miRNA Expression and Function As any other gene the evolutionary processes that gives rise to new miRNAs mainly by duplication or de novo origin Berezikov Meunier et al takes place on certain regions of the genome that may overlap or not to preexisting gene loci In a recent study Meunier et al showed that all vertebrate species analyzed Platypus Opossum Mouse Macaque and have a significant excess of intragenic miRNAs with on average of them overlapping to introns Curiously the proportions of intronic miRNAs are even higher for those of recent origin suggesting that introns are hotspots for new miRNA origination Moreover the transcriptional orientation of intragenic miRNAs is highly biased toward the same strand orientation of their host genes Rodriguez et al et al Meunier et al Hinske et al Given the large size of vertebrate genomes why do miRNAs apparently have such preference to emerge in intragenic regions Which evidences support the role of natural selection shaping this pattern and what advantages miRNAs might take from such genomic organization To address these questions et al investigated the patterns of emergence and expression of human miRNAs along the vertebrate evolution considering the evolutionary origin of their host genes i e whether miRNAs are intergenic mapped to old genes before fish and tetrapods or to young genes after the Similar to previous studies Iwama et al it was shown that most human miRNAs have a relatively recent origin emerging in the primate order Though an interesting pattern was revealed the majority of those young miRNAs are intragenic and preferentially embedded within old host genes even when controlled by host gene length intronic and expression level Expression breadth analyses showed that young miRNAs hosted by old genes were more broadly expressed in more than their intergenic counterparts On the other hand miRNAs hosted by young genes showed a bias to expression when compared to the intergenic ones or those within old genes The same conclusions held when a very stringent miRNA annotation provided by Fromm et al was considered since several miRBase entries do not represent bonafide miRNAs Chiang et al Taylor et al Fromm et al It is well established that expression breadth is negatively correlated with evolutionary rates Wolf et al Park and Choi meaning that overall conserved genes are highly and broadly expressed whereas less conserved genes tend to have low and narrow expression What turns out is that the expression of intragenic miRNAs is tightly coupled to their genomic environment especially in regard to the evolutionary ages of their host genes In a mechanistic way this is clearly connected with the of gene pairs by shared regulatory elements a very event Baskerville and Bartel Ozsolak et al Marsico et al Hence the maintenance of miRNAs embedded in genic regions may be indicative of some evolutionary constraint since young and older intragenic miRNAs are biased toward host gene sense orientation as well as preferential emergence within old host genes In addition same age miRNAs show differential expression breadth depending on their genomic context a pattern that is maintained not only during recent g but also over longer periods Such pattern is observed for miRNAs originated in amniotes g or in placental mammals g presenting higher or lower expression breadth depending on the age of their host genes et al In particular for young intragenic miRNAs being hosted by old genes could be beneficial at least during an initial adaptive phase because of the expression broadness achieved through a presumably favorable transcriptional environment Instead of readily relying on the settlement of their own regulatory apparatus young miRNAs would initially been benefited by their regulatory elements albeit they may acquire independent regulation afterward et al Supporting this notion it has been suggested that young and intragenic miRNAs are more likely to be regulated by shared promoters whereas old miRNAs are frequently regulated by their independent intronic promoters Marsico et al In addition as old host genes provide higher expression breadth for those young miRNAs it would in principle increase the opportunities for new target interactions in different tissues From such perspective the host transcriptional environment could facilitate the initial expression of young miRNAs and thereafter contribute to the process of miRNA functionalization The location of a gene in the genome is clearly related to its expression as revealed by transgene insertion experiments et al and global expression analyses of gene neighborhoods Caron et al Purmann et al Michalak Nevertheless some of the observed expression changes in gene vicinity may not be subjected to selection but rather it would be a consequence of expression changes in a close gene under strong selection Recently Ghanbarian and Hurst demonstrated that expression changes in humans relative to the common ancestor coordinately drive changes in expression of the neighbors of a focal gene and that this effect is stronger as the distance between genes are shorter Therefore the genomic context still may yield important effects on the expression and perhaps the fixation of novel miRNAs that are not under direct selection Evolutionary Conservation and Novelties From Genomic Context The phylogenetic distribution of miRNAs in vertebrates is distinguished by the presence of deeply conserved and abundant clade or repertoires Berezikov et al Wheeler et al Meunier et al Fromm et al Although the evolution of miRNA sequences have been investigated Lyu et al Ninova et al the conserved patterns and evolutionary innovations that arose due to interspecific differences in the genomic context are largely underexplored One of the few studies to address this issue compared the genomic location and expression of miRNAs during developmental stages of medaka fish zebrafish chicken and mouse Ason et al It was demonstrated that spatial expression differences can be related to changes either in the miRNA location and copy number variation rather than to sequence divergence Ason et al Actually the miRNA genomic location is thought to influence their expression divergence as and intragenic miRNAs tend to be more similarly expressed among species than intergenic ones et al Such kind of expression constraint linked to a conserved genomic context is clearly observed for and its host gene et al Homologous sequences of are found across amniotes with identical mature sequences from human to chicken Gene order and location of in the second intron of are also preserved Figure Although is annotated as intergenic in chicken predicted transcripts with an intron overlapping are annotated Expression analyses reveal a strongly conserved pattern among human rhesus macaque mouse and indicating concomitant expression of and Shen et al with highest abundance in heart Figure The host gene is a muscarinic cholinergic receptor involved in cardiac chronotropic and inotropic of muscle effects Brodde and Michel and it has been associated with cardiomyopathy Zhang et al Notably dysregulation of is also reported in cardiac disease Cooley et al and is involved with proliferation of human coronary artery smooth cells Sun et al suggesting an important functional connection between and FIGURE Genomic context conservation of intragenic miRNAs The human embedded within reveals a highly conserved pattern in terms of sequence and expression Alignments from the UCSC genome browser indicate the preservation of throughout amniotes with few differing bases blue and identical mature sequences base scores indicate strong purifying selection on this region and are with highest levels in heart a pattern conserved in other species The human encoded within has homologous sequences only in primates The expression of follows its host pattern with higher levels in brain and cerebellum possibly reflecting rapid evolution Expression of in rhesus was not detected Expression data were obtained from Brawand et al and Meunier et al and processed in et al Tissues are heart brain cerebellum kidney and testis As mentioned earlier the transcriptional environment of host genes may act as a key factor to promote the expression of newly emerged miRNAs This phenomenon is well illustrated by the encoded within Figure This host gene is a fucosyltransferase throughout animals Costache et al Juliant et al that catalyzes fucosylation of glycoproteins which is essential for activating growth factor receptors Liu et al while its deletion has lethal effects in mice Wang et al is ubiquitously expressed in human tissues Mele et al and seems to follow its host expression pattern Figure Considering the young evolutionary age of its expression levels and breadth are unusually high thus being frequently altered in different types of cancer Zhou et al Zheng et al It is interesting that has emerged as a promising predictive biomarker in colorectal cancer Verma et al Rasmussen et al exhibiting strong association with oxaliplatin chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of metastatic colorectal resistance Rasmussen et al Another singular feature of miRNAs is their frequent occurrence in clusters originated through tandem or duplications or by de novo mutations either in introns or intergenic regions Berezikov Such genomic organization is prone to greatly affect the evolution of newly emerged miRNAs According to Wang et al members of the same cluster tend to exhibit coordinated expression and to target overlapping sets of genes The authors proposed that clustering arrangement and by developing functions related to the miRNAs in the same cluster would help the initial survival of these young miRNAs until the cluster is settled up by purifying selection Otherwise the most usual fate of de novo newly emerged miRNAs would to undergo rapid degeneration In further support of this model clustered young miRNAs indeed present significant signs of adaptive changes that probably drive them to functional constraints associated with the older members of the cluster Wang et al Interactions Functional and Evolutionary Implications If a recently emerged miRNA is expressed and integrated into regulatory networks through consistent and biologically relevant target interactions it will have more chances to become functional and be retained afterward over long periods Chen and Rajewsky Lyu et al Therefore young miRNAs originated in a genomic context able to boost their expression in multiple tissues would favor target recognition This idea is consistent with the previous observation that young miRNAs emerged within old host genes are expressed in more tissues and tend to have more predicted targets compared to young intergenic ones et al We therefore suggested a miRNA evolution model that takes into account not only the miRNAs themselves but also their genomic context et al Figure Hence young miRNAs hosted by old genes would gain higher expression breadth benefited by their transcriptional activity thus enabling many target interactions that at first glance are mostly neutral Chen and Rajewsky Nozawa et al but could be stabilized by natural selection over time On the other hand as young intergenic miRNAs tend to have narrower expression and apparently less targets to interact with they could undergo faster degeneration Figure This degeneration scenario is also most likely to happen with miRNAs emerged within young hosts because of their general expression signature et al FIGURE Model of miRNA evolution Young miRNAs emerged within old genes are expressed in more tissues and therefore could interact with diverse set of targets possibly enhancing the chances of functionalization and fixation through time In contrast as young intergenic miRNAs tend to be expressed in very limited target interactions could contribute to their faster degeneration Evolutionary sequence conservation has been successfully introduced to reduce the number of and to increase the ratio in target predictions Instead of helping identifying conserved pathways and relationships among miRNAs and their targets Hausser and Zavolan this requirement comes with a drawback since it can only be applied to miRNAs and target genes that have conservation data available and which are not Indeed a recent study demonstrated that target sites identified by immunoprecipitation data are rarely conserved between distantly related species but extensive conservation is observed between closely related ones Xu et al Even when considering sites there is evidence of selective constraints compared to sites across the region suggesting that most of targets might be functional at least for a short evolutionary period A striking example of this condition is the target site for in the of the transcription factor whose regulation altered phenotypes such as proliferation and migration in a manner McLoughlin et al Despite of the recent advances on the characterization of operating mechanisms that guide interactions we are only on the verge of understanding how newly emerged miRNAs in different genomic contexts are integrated into regulatory networks as well as how their novel target interactions contribute to phenotypic plasticity Population Biology Perspective for the Genome Architecture of miRNAs Population biology studies at the genome level have been proved to be promising tools enhancing our understanding on how genetic elements are interconnected spatially and temporally et al Sudmant et al Most of miRNA population studies have focused on the impact of single nucleotide variants localized inside the seed and the mature regions to analyze conservation patterns target diversification and differential disease susceptibility g Barbash et al et al Gallego et al Except for few studies of miRNA expression quantitative trait loci g Huan et al the evolution of miRNA genomic architecture has not been deeply investigated using a population biology framework It is still unknown if variation in miRNAs sequence expression and target sites across populations are more relevant for uncovering the mechanisms of phenotypic evolution and disease than other genetic variation On one hand due to its folded structure and small size miRNAs are more likely to emerge de novo than novel protein coding genes Berezikov Diversification of miRNA target repertoire may be more prone to appear as result of simple sequence modifications such as direct mutation seed or hairpin shifting and arm switching Berezikov Therefore variation on sites indeed can lead to phenotypic innovation as exemplified by the lineage diversification of cichlid fishes Loh et al Franchini et al On the other hand as target mRNAs can be regulated subtly by several miRNAs detecting phenotypical effects by population variation seems to be harder than for genetic variation in regulatory or coding regions Indeed most of single nucleotide polymorphisms involved in the creation of novel miRNA target sites does not correlate with phenotypic differences among humans Saunders et al Nonetheless it is possible that genomic comparisons of different individuals can give insights on the origination process of miRNAs as previously done for other genetic elements Hatcher For instance the basis of retrogene origination in metazoans has been recently deciphered through Drosophila population data Flanking regions signatures of polymorphic retrocopies revealed that long terminal repeat retrotransposons have mediate their formation Tan et al miRNAs are mostly originated de novo or by duplication Meunier et al but mechanistic details on how those processes occur are still unknown Population genomics might help uncover those components through the identification of mutational signatures attached to polymorphic miRNAs that are usually erased by time and throughout their fixation In addition comparing fixed patterns present in different species to polymorphic states observed in a group of individuals are useful tools for contrasting genomic features driven by natural selection to patterns produced by mutation bias Long et al Notable this type of comparison helped to support the hypothesis in which natural selection drives retrogene duplication from the X chromosome to the autosomes in Drosophila and humans Schrider et al Navarro and Galante Therefore the analyses of different human populations can give further support to the adapted pattern of miRNAs organized inside old protein coding host genes Furthermore as miRNAs expression and targeting has been shown to be implicated in a wide of human diseases Mendell and Olson seed and mature region variants found among ethnic populations become clinically important et al More specifically there are distinct miRNA profiles in diseases between African and European descendants g Huang et al Heegaard et al which could be responsible for differences among those populations in susceptibility to diseases drug sensitiveness and biomarker diagnostics et al Therefore should worth investigating if ethnic group variation on miRNA genomic context have also significant role in human health From the discussion above it turns out that the genomic context as an outcome of natural selection imposes evolutionary constraints to maintain the structural and functional integrity of its genetic elements Moreover it can also propel the evolutionary fate of new elements that arise in a suitable environment eventually accelerating the process of functionalization Therefore evolutionary models tackling the chromatin organization will be of extreme value to pursue the general principles that afford those processes take place throughout genomes Author Contributions GSF and MDV conceived the study GSF LCH PAFG and MDV wrote the manuscript All authors revised and approved it for publication Conflict of Interest Peroxide Treatment of Escherichia coli and Serotypes on Romaine Lettuce Mei Tang Joshua Bach Susan Kostrzynska Magdalena Guelph Research and Development Centre Agriculture and Canada Guelph ON Canada is cited in accordance with accepted academic practice No use distribution or reproduction is permitted which does not comply with these terms Disease outbreaks of Escherichia coli and serotypes associated with leafy green vegetables are becoming a growing concern A better understanding of the behavior of VTEC particularly serotypes on lettuce under stress conditions is necessary for designing more effective control strategies Hydrogen peroxide O can be used as a sanitizer to reduce the microbial load in leafy green vegetables particularly in fresh produce destined for the organic market In this study we tested the hypothesis that H O treatment of contaminated lettuce affects in the same manner transcription of and virulence genes in VTEC strains representing and serotypes Six VTEC isolates representing serotypes NM NM and were included in this study The results indicate that mM H O caused a population reduction of log to control in all six VTEC strains present on romaine lettuce Following the treatment the transcription of genes related to oxidative stress oxyR and sodA general stress uspA and rpoS starvation phoA acid stress gadA gadB and gadW and virulence and fliC were dramatically downregulated in all six VTEC serotypes P compared to not treated control samples Therefore VTEC and serotypes on lettuce showed similar survival rates and gene transcription profiles in response to mM H O treatment Thus the results derived from this study provide a basic understanding of the influence of H O treatment on the survival and virulence of VTEC and serotypes on lettuce Escherichia coli serotypes lettuce decontamination hydrogen peroxide treatment gene transcription Agriculture and Canada Introduction Escherichia coli also referred to as Shiga toxin E coli often cause diseases such as hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome Croxen et al Karpman and Stahl Karmali Although VTEC serotype is commonly identified in human diseases serogroups have been increasingly associated with serious outbreaks and were recently responsible for more than of STEC illness in U S et al Parsons et al CDC In the incidence of confirmed VTEC infections was higher than in Huang et al More than of infections linked to VTEC were caused by serotypes and the Top Saito et al Brooks et al Folster et al Bradley et al Brown et al In enteroaggregative E coli caused the biggest outbreak in Germany This strain produces and is one of the most virulent strains of VTEC Buchholz et al Zangari et al Karmali Fresh leafy green vegetables are an important part of a healthy diet due to their richness in minerals vitamins and phytochemicals However leafy green vegetables can be contaminated by pathogenic bacteria such as VTEC during growth harvesting and transportation leading to subsequent illnesses and outbreaks Wachtel et al Solomon et al Islam et al Delaquis et al A number of surveys have shown an increase in foodborne outbreaks linked to contaminated leafy green vegetables Harris et al Sivapalasingam et al Rangel et al Lynch et al Painter et al Herman et al Although the contamination can be minimized by preventing produce exposure to sources of pathogenic bacteria including contaminated water soil and animals the occasional contamination of leafy green vegetables on farms by VTEC can still occur which leads to contaminated produce entering the processing lines Olaimat and Holley Therefore effectively reducing the contamination during processing is crucial to ensure the safety of fresh leafy green vegetables Chlorine has been widely used as a sanitizer to reduce the microbial load in vegetables Beuchat et al However chlorine may react to form potentially carcinogenic or mutagenic products Hurst In addition the formed when sodium hypochlorite sanitizer commonly used in the fresh produce reacts with organic compounds have been shown to increase the risk of bladder cancer Villanueva et al Hydrogen peroxide O is a potential alternative to chlorine treatment and breaks down to ecologically friendly water and oxygen Linley et al In addition H O has been approved for use in organic postharvest processing systems As such this sanitizer could be used for decontamination of fresh produce destined for organic market To date several studies have been conducted on the gene expression in pure culture of E coli under oxidative stress Wang et al Allen and Griffiths Mei et al In addition using H O as a sanitizer on fresh produce to reduce E coli was investigated Sapers et al Huang et al However the survival and gene transcription of VTEC serotypes under stress conditions on lettuce remain largely unknown In this study the behaviors of and VTEC serotypes in response to H O treatment on lettuce were evaluated Materials and Methods Bacterial Strains and Growth Conditions Six VTEC strains were tested in this study E coli NM and NM E coli was included in the present study because it is prototype strain Serotypes and are predominant serotypes worldwide therefore strains representing these serotypes have been investigated in this study In addition VTEC isolated from German outbreak was selected because this strain is highly virulent and is linked to fresh produce outbreak All the strains except were of human origin E coli was isolated from raw hamburger meat linked to an outbreak of HC Further details regarding these strains have been published previously Mei et al E coli possesses genes encoding and intimin gene eae and flagellin gene fliC VTEC and do not have genes VTEC strains NM and NM do not have genes encoding and flagellin Enteroaggregative E coli strain does not possess genes encoding and intimin For simplicity VTEC strains will be referred to by their serotype as each strain has its distinct serotype All the strains were grown in Tryptic soy broth at with shaking for h Subsequently mL of h culture of each VTEC strain was inoculated into mL TSB and incubated for h at with shaking The bacterial cells in logarithmic phase were collected washed twice with sterile distilled water and used to inoculate lettuce samples Hydrogen Peroxide Treatment of Contaminated Lettuce Romaine lettuce was purchased from a local grocery store in Guelph The outer leaves were removed and the remaining leaves were cut into cm slices grams of the leaves were weighed placed into sterile polyethylene stomacher bags and inoculated with mL of bacterial suspension CFU The leaves were massaged for min to distribute the bacterial suspension evenly on the leaves Subsequently mL of H O was added to the bag to achieve a final concentration of mM The negative control sample contained lettuce leaves with mL of autoclaved distilled water and mL H O The control sample contained mL of bacterial suspension and mL of autoclaved distilled water The bags were incubated at room temperature for min After incubation mL of culture was taken from each stomacher bag and serially diluted with buffered peptone water Subsequently of each dilution was spread on cefixime MacConkey agar plates in duplicate The plates were incubated for h at and the CFU mL was calculated Additionally mL samples from controls and each stomacher bag treated with mM H O were collected for RNA extraction RNA Extraction and cDNA Synthesis Bacterial cells were concentrated by centrifugation before RNA extraction After taking samples from controls and each stomacher bag treated with mM H O each mL sample was added to mL of RNAprotect Bacteria Reagent The samples were centrifuged for min at g and supernatants were decanted prior to RNA extraction RNA was isolated using the RNeasy Mini Kit Mississauga ON following the instructions for bacteria Contaminating genomic DNA was removed from each RNA preparation using the Turbo TM kit Cambridge according to the instructions for DNase treatments Total RNA concentration was determined using a Thermo Scientific Nanodrop Subsequently of RNA was using SuperScript III Carlsbad CA according to the instructions A no reverse transcriptase control was included for each RNA sample PCR All and virulence genes tested in this study are described in Table Transcription investigated in this study A population reduction of log was observed for all VTEC strains on lettuce following treatment with mM H O Table A previous study in our laboratory using the same VTEC strains suspended in TSB reported greater sensitivity to H O For instance treatment of pure broth culture of VTEC with mM H O resulted in a log reduction and mM H O caused a log reduction in population of E coli Tang and Kostrzynska Therefore the results derived from these studies demonstrate that H O treatment is less effective in lettuce decontamination compared to its effect on reducing VTEC populations in pure cultures Previous investigations showed that several factors such as organic loads of produce Gonzalez et al or wash Nou and Luo and leaf age Brandl and Amundson can influence the efficacy of sanitizer to inactivate E coli on fresh produce These studies indicate that the lettuce leaves may help to protect bacteria making it harder to eliminate pathogens from lettuce Indeed bacterial cells on lettuce may be physically sequestered from H O exposure In addition organic molecules released by lettuce will react with H O and therefore reduce the effective exposure to H O Therefore in order to choose an effective treatment to reduce the pathogens on leafy greens it is important to understand the behavior of bacteria on lettuce under different stress conditions To get a better understanding of the response to H O treatment in different VTEC serotypes in the present study the transcription of genes related to stress and virulence in and serotypes on lettuce was evaluated Different gene transcription profiles following exposure to H O were observed in VTEC strains on lettuce compared to pure broth cultures Mei et al H O caused dramatic downregulation of and virulence genes in VTEC strains present on lettuce including and serotypes Ten genes were downregulated in all six VTEC strains on lettuce Figures However only three genes were upregulated These genes belong to different regulation systems in E coli and respond to various environmental conditions by adjusting behavior accordingly to protect cells from damaging System Response oxyR sodA and soxR Superoxide dismutases and catalases are employed by E coli to respond to superoxide and peroxide stress There are three SODs including MnSOD sodA FeSOD and CuZnSOD and two catalases and HPII encoded by katG and katE in E coli These SODs and catalase genes are regulated by two major oxidative stress regulons OxyR and SoxRS Chiang and Schellhorn In the presence of oxidative stress OxyR can sense H O and be converted to the oxidized form subsequently activating transcription of the OxyR regulon genes such as katG dps and oxyR which protect the cell from H O toxicity Storz et al Farr and Kogoma Chiang and Schellhorn In this study the transcription of oxyR was downregulated in all VTEC strains Figures this may cause a reduction in catalase expression increasing peroxide sensitivity SoxRS is another key regulon triggered under oxidative stress in E coli It is positively regulated by agents such as paraquat and constitutes a regulatory system in which SoxR activated as a transcriptional activator induces the expression of soxS and the resulting increased levels of SoxS protein regulate the transcription of the various genes important for responding to oxidative stress Demple and Nunoshiba et al Chiang and Schellhorn The genes controlled by soxRS include sodA nfo repair endonuclease micF regulator of ompF and zwf Christman et al Greenberg et al Tsaneva and Weiss In the present study following exposure of VTEC strains on lettuce to mM H O the transcription of soxR in E coli slightly increased whereas the transcription of soxR decreased to below the detectable level in Therefore SodA reduction may be attributed to the reduction or only slight induction of soxR Manchado et al reported that the expression of genes katG and dps were induced when the concentration of H O was from to while the higher concentration H O resulted in the upregulation of soxS and sodA That study suggests that the expression of oxyR or soxRS is In addition downregulation of soxR was also observed in VTEC broth cultures exposed to oxidative stress Mei et al however the transcription of sodA was significantly P increased in pure cultures of all VTEC strains The inconsistent results of expression of soxR and sodA may indicate that sodA can react to superoxide stress SoxRS is not the sole regulator of sodA gene General Stress Response uspA and rpoS and Cold Shock Response cspA cspC and cspE Escherichia coli contains a large CspA family consisting of nine homologous cold inducible proteins CspA to CspI among which CspA is the major one produced at and is negatively downregulated by cspC Whereas CspC and CspE are constitutively produced at and are not temperature regulated Yamanaka et al Etchegaray et al Phadtare and Inouye It has been reported that CspC and CspE are important regulators of the expression of RpoS a global stress response regulator and UspA u niversal s tress p rotein A responding to various general stresses Nystrom and Neidhardt In addition genes such as dps and katG are upregulated or downregulated by the overexpression or deletion of cspC and cspE Phadtare and Inouye Phadtare et al Therefore CspC and CspE play important roles in the stress response of E coli Upregulation of cspC and cspE in all six VTEC strains on lettuce was observed in the present study Figures However uspA and rpoS were downregulated and a minor change in the transcription of dps was observed Interestingly the transcription of cspC was downregulated in broth cultures of all VTEC strains exposed to mM H O at Mei et al On the other hand in the present study cspC was upregulated in VTEC strains on lettuce treated with mM H O at room temperature Previous investigation showed that CspC and CspE cannot be induced under some stress conditions like M NaCl M KCl ethanol pH pH temperature of or Phadtare and Inouye It is possible that a different concentration of H O used for lettuce decontamination as well as environmental factors such as H O released from lettuce leaves as well as nutrients present in lettuce samples and natural microbiota contributed to the induction of cspC and cspE More interestingly contrary results of transcription of cspC and cspE observed in response to H O treatment of VTEC pure cultures and in the same strains present on lettuce suggest that VTEC may react to the same stress differently in different environments However it is not possible to rule out that induction of cold stress genes in present study was more of the effect of temperature change combined with peroxide treatment Centrifugation of bacterial cells using refrigerated centrifuge following VTEC exposure on lettuce to H O could influence transcription of cold shock genes Further studies are required to gain a better understanding of the stress conditions that affect the cspC and cspE gene transcription in VTEC present on lettuce Starvation Stress Response phoA and dps The gene phoA encoding alkaline phosphatase was induced under a condition but was not synthesized in normal growth medium Han and Lee The phoA is a member of pho regulon regulated by a system et al The phoA was significantly downregulated in all the VTEC strains on lettuce tested in this study Figures Furthermore downregulation of phoA was observed in most VTEC strains when pure cultures were treated with H O Mei et al Therefore further studies are needed to test if H O treatment changes the sensitivity of VTEC strains to condition The H O can cause lethality of the bacterial cells through several mechanisms It has been proposed that the primary cause of cell inactivation by H O or other oxidative agents is DNA damage Storz et al Thus it is important for the cells to cope with stresses by inducing the production of a variety of DNA repair enzymes as well as catalases Glutathione also acts to protect cells from oxidative stress In addition D NA binding p rotein from s tarved cells protects cells during environmental stresses including oxidative stress and nutritional deprivation Almiron et al Calhoun and Kwon Dps protects cells from harmful oxidative radicals by DNA binding iron storage and by binding and oxidizing Fe ions at ferroxidase centers Furthermore Dps may regulate the expression of DNA repair enzymes and catalases necessary for stress resistance Zheng et al reported that the expression of dps considerably increased when the cells were exposed to mM H O for min However only minor upregulation of dps was observed in this study for most of VTEC strains on lettuce Figures Mismatch Repair Response mutS MutS is a member of MMR system which helps to maintain chromosome stability in E coli MutS binds to the mismatches and initiates the MMR on daughter DNA strands Modrich and Lahue Schofield and Hsieh MMR has also been shown to be involved in the repair of oxidative DNA damage which causes spontaneous lesion or Michaels and Miller Tchou and Grollman Lu et al Studies have shown that the amount of MutS in E coli remarkably decreased when cells were in the stationary phase and under starvation stress and the expression of MutS repair protein was negatively regulated by the RpoS and Hfq global regulators Feng et al Tsui et al Li et al In the present study mutS was upregulated following exposure of VTEC on lettuce to H O Figures This upregulation may be caused by significantly downregulated expression of RpoS which is a negative regulator of mutS Acid Response gadA gadB and gadW pathogenic E coli must be able to survive in the extremely acidic environment of the stomach and resist very low pH for several hours Peterson et al Previous studies have shown that a total of genes comprise an acid fitness island including a glutamate decarboxylase system and three transcriptional regulators GadX and of the GAD enzymes which renders E coli the ability to survive strong acidic stress Hommais et al Ma et al Bergholz et al Mates et al E coli produce two isozymes of GAD encoded by the gadA and gadB genes which are induced by GadX at any pH while GadW represses expression of gadX GadW activates the expression of gadA and gadB only in the absence of GadX Ma et al Tucker et al In addition it has been reported that the expression of gadA and gadBC were induced when bacteria were cultured in acidified medium treated with acetate and during entry into stationary phase Selinger et al Arnold et al Tucker et al However the expression of regulators GadX and GadW under the same conditions were unknown In the present study gadA gadB and gadW were significantly downregulated in all six VTEC strains on lettuce Figures We suspect that the expression of gadX was also downregulated in response to H O which subsequently resulted in the downregulation of gadA and gadB Furthermore the results indicate that following H O treatment VTEC on lettuce may become more sensitive to acid stress which decreases the viability of pathogens under low pH Virulence Factors by eae and fliC Production of Stx is the definitive virulence factor of VTEC and serotypes Croxen et al Scheutz Smith et al Franz et al Stx produced by VTEC can be classified into two types and There are three subtypes of c and seven subtypes of b c d e f Although both toxins could cause bloody diarrhea and HUS a specific subset of subtypes and have a higher association with HC and HUS than subtypes or other subtypes Scheutz Stx are encoded on bacteriophage genomes that are integrated into bacterial chromosome As such the biology of the phages influences the expression of and Production and release of toxins depend on induction of these bacteriophages Croxen et al Scheutz Amongst the VTEC strains tested in this study E coli produced both and E coli produced only and the remaining four strains produced only In this study both and genes were dramatically downregulated in all VTEC strains on lettuce following exposure to H O Figures Many VTEC strains produce attaching and effacing lesions which are controlled by the locus of enterocyte effacement Croxen et al Scheutz Although AE lesions are not essential for bloody diarrhea and HUS the majority of strains implicated in these syndromes are Intimin encoded by eae E coli attaching and gene is responsible for intimate adhesion of VTEC to the intestinal epithelium and formation of AE lesions Intimin binds to the cell receptor Tir which is translocated by the pathogen to the enterocyte via a type III secretion system Croxen et al The presence of eae gene is strongly correlated to the presence of genes encoding many other virulence factors Franz et al In addition VTEC strains with eae and genes have been associated with HUS and bloody diarrhea Scheutz In the present study the transcription of eae for E coli which is changed only slightly following H O treatment Figures Thus further studies about eae regulation and the virulence of VTEC strains under different stress conditions are needed Production of flagella is another contributor to the pathogenicity of VTEC Gyles Flagella are mainly responsible for motility chemotaxis and secretion of virulence factors The key structural component of the flagellum filament is encoded by the fliC gene In our studies the transcription of fliC was dramatically downregulated in all four motile VTEC strains on lettuce treated with H O Figures In addition fliC was downregulated in pure broth cultures exposed to H O Mei et al These results suggest that H O treatment affects motility of VTEC strains Conclusion H O treatment caused less dramatic reduction in VTEC populations on lettuce compared to pure broth cultures which indicates that VTEC are protected from H O on leafy greens Consequently higher concentration of H O or other sanitizers are required to reduce and eliminate VTEC on lettuce As such the results derived from this study showed the importance of food matrix in studying the effect of sanitizers on survival rate of VTEC In addition VTEC strains on lettuce showed similar transcription patterns of in response to treatment with mM H O The transcription of genes related to oxidative stress general stress acid stress and some virulence genes were significantly downregulated in six VTEC serotypes Consequently VTEC strains on lettuce may become more sensitive to acid stress following H O treatment Interestingly different gene transcription patterns in response to H O were observed in VTEC strains on lettuce compared to pure broth cultures Mei et al Particularly sodA gene encoding manganese SOD was significantly upregulated in pure cultures of all VTEC serotypes however this gene was downregulated in the same strains present on lettuce In addition Stx genes were upregulated in broth culture of E coli and downregulated in most VTEC serotypes on lettuce following H O treatment It is possible that factors released from lettuce leaves and natural microbiota present in lettuce samples contributed to different gene transcription patterns in VTEC strains on lettuce compared to broth cultures Author Contributions All authors have made substantial direct and
