with these terms The majority of research in the Staphylococcus field has been dedicated to the understanding of Staphylococcus aureus infections In contrast there is limited information on infections by Staphylococci and how the host responds to them S epidermidis a member of the Staphylococci is an important commensal organism of the human skin and mucous and there is emerging evidence of its benefit for human health in fighting off harmful microorganisms However S epidermidis can cause opportunistic infections which include particularly infections on indwelling medical devices These often can disseminate into the and in fact S epidermidis is the most frequent cause of nosocomial sepsis The increasing use of medical implants and the dramatic shift in the patient demographic population in recent years have contributed significantly to the rise of S epidermidis infections Furthermore treatment has been complicated by the emergence of strains Today S epidermidis is a major nosocomial pathogen posing significant medical and economic burdens In this review we present the current understanding of mechanisms of host defense against the prototypical CoNS species S epidermidis as a commensal of the skin and mucous membranes and during infection and sepsis staphylococci Staphylococcus epidermidis innate immunity host defense sepsis biofilms infection Division of Intramural Research National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases ZIA Introduction staphylococci are a heterogeneous group of staphylococcal species classified clinically by the absence of the enzyme coagulase This distinguishes them from Staphylococcus aureus and a few clinically less important species Today CoNS are the most commonly isolated bacteria in clinical cultures and have emerged as major nosocomial pathogens Risk factors for CoNS infection include the presence of indwelling medical implants such as intravascular catheters or immunosuppression due to cancer treatment or HIV AIDS Treatment of CoNS infections is complicated by the emergence of strains as particularly MRSE S epidermidis et al CoNS are an integral part of the normal flora on the human skin and mucous membranes and preferentially colonize moist areas et al S epidermidis the most common CoNS species recovered from clinical cultures colonizes the armpit groin anterior nares conjunctiva toe webs and perineal area and Musselwhite While usually innocuous or even beneficial colonizers once the host epithelial barrier is compromised CoNS such as S epidermidis can cause serious infections In fact CoNS infections account for the majority of bacterial sepsis and foreign infections with S epidermidis being the most significant species in that regard et al The host immune response to S epidermidis the mechanism of immune tolerance and the immune benefits that S epidermidis commensals can provide are just beginning to be unraveled This review will provide the latest research on the host response to S epidermidis as commensals and as opportunistic bacteria in the context of biofilm and septic infections The host immune response to S epidermidis as a commensal There is increasing evidence that the skin microbiota in general have an important impact on the immune system and Tamoutounour Despite CoNS being among the most important skin colonizers specific studies on the host immune response to CoNS colonization and establishment have been limited Those that are available have focused on the immune response to skin colonization by the prototypical CoNS species S epidermidis and the benefits such colonization provides to the host For example the Gallo group has described potentially beneficial functions of S epidermidis as a skin commensal Namely Lai et al reported that S epidermidis lipoteichoic acid through a mechanism involving TLR reduces skin inflammation et al The same authors also later reported that S epidermidis not other produces a not further characterized substance of less than kD that activates and thereby induces antimicrobial peptide production which increased the capacity of cell lysates to inhibit growth of group A Streptococcus and S aureus et al While these results underline a beneficial function of S epidermidis on the skin regarding the stimulating factor they have to be seen in light of the fact that the frequently reported activation of by LTA has been challenged LTA purification is extremely difficult and often contains lipopeptide contaminants including in commercial preparations et al These findings thus certainly require further assessment using isogenic mutants of S epidermidis to verify the nature of the stimulating factor Figure Model of the host response to S epidermidis colonization S epidermidis colonizes the skin epidermis a highly organized structure composed mainly of keratinocytes In response to S epidermidis colonization pattern recognition receptors such as on keratinocytes bind to poorly characterized secreted by S epidermidis to stimulate a signaling cascade that results for example in the production of the antimicrobial peptides and These antimicrobial peptides provide protection from cutaneous S aureus and Group A Streptococcus infections S epidermidis colonization induces a specific T reg response which is essential for immune tolerance toward S epidermidis as a commensal Immune tolerance is believed to be established only during the neonatal period as colonization in adult mice failed to establish tolerance In a different model based on results obtained in adult mice skin colonization by S epidermidis triggers a specific response Primed in the skin draining lymph node by dendritic cells these T cells enhance the innate antimicrobial defense and prevent invasion by the fungus C albicans Scharschmidt et al showed that colonization with S epidermidis triggered a local as well as systemic specific T cell response as demonstrated by the enrichment of specific T cells in both the lymph nodes and the spleen et al This group engineered the S epidermidis skin isolate strain to express the peptide antigen linked to a fluorescent protein To achieve colonization they applied CFUs of the engineered strain to the dorsal skin of mice every days for a total of three applications Using this model the authors illustrated that expansion of specifically regulatory T reg cells plays a critical role in the immune tolerance to S epidermidis Such tolerance however required early bacterial colonization during the neonatal stage as colonization in adult mice did not establish tolerance The work by Scharschmidt et al is especially intriguing as it provides the scientific rationale for the modulation of the skin microbiota in the neonatal period as a therapeutic option to treat inflammatory skin diseases and in particular for atopic dermatitis The skin of AD patients is often colonized by S aureus et al Several studies show that S epidermidis is the second most common microbe isolated from skin lesions et al While this does not directly implicate S epidermidis in the pathogenesis of AD due to its normal and frequent abundance on the skin in the most recent of those studies Hon et al examined bacterial isolates from AD patients and found that S epidermidis is present in the most severely skin lesions et al Thus the previously suggested antagonistic relationship between S epidermidis and S aureus et al Iwase et al did not translate to less disease in their study Rather the results suggested that S epidermidis colonization is associated with more severe AD disease Certainly further studies are required to evaluate the role of S epidermidis in AD pathogenesis and the nature of the relationship between S aureus and S epidermidis in AD lesions Naik et al demonstrated that S epidermidis colonization in adult mice induces a T cell response et al In this study the group applied ml of CFU per ml of S epidermidis across the entire mouse skin surface every other day for a total of four applications a procedure by which they reported to obtain stable colonization The T cells induced in this study however were T cells rather than T cells as in the Scharschmidt et al study et al The authors showed that these T cells provided immunity to cutaneous C albicans infection however they did not examine whether this also provides immunity to other pathogens notably S aureus et al Both the Scharschmidt et al and Naik et al studies examined the host immune response to S epidermidis colonization yet their findings are quite different These differences can be attributed to the nuances in the setup of the mouse models or possibly also the specific S epidermidis strains used Despite the differences in the results collectively the two studies showed that colonization with S epidermidis induces an adaptive T cell response in mice It is unclear however if such immune signature to S epidermidis colonization is also observed in humans Immunity against S epidermidis in infections Very few studies have been performed to assess the immune response to CoNS infections especially as compared to S aureus Most of those studies have focused on S epidermidis CoNS infections often occur in patients with medical implants with S epidermidis being the most likely species to be recovered et al Biofilms are complex spatially diverse agglomerations of bacterial cells enclosed within an amorphous extracellular matrix composed of extracellular DNA proteins and polysaccharides infections are extremely resistant to antibiotic treatment for several reasons including reduced metabolism and hampered penetration through the extracellular matrix and O Toole Consequently treatment often requires surgical removal of the infected device or tissue In the US alone approximately billion is spent annually for the treatment and management of orthopedic infections Parvizi et al In general the host immune response to an S epidermidis infection is not protective or sufficient to clear the infection Hence most S epidermidis infections are chronic Most studies conducted on the subject thus far are studies that have compared versus planktonic bacteria Results from several studies suggest that S epidermidis biofilms induce attenuation in phagocytic function and production of cytokines when compared to their planktonic counterparts Conflicting findings have been reported on the effects of S epidermidis biofilms on phagocytic activity Two studies reported that adherence and phagocytosis by human neutrophils and primary human macrophages were significantly enhanced when stimulated with bacteria et al Spiliopoulou et al while others reported that the biofilm exopolysaccharide polysaccharide intercellular adhesin et al plays an essential role in the attenuation of phagocytic capacity of murine peritoneal macrophages and Wu murine macrophages et al and human PMNs There is consensus in the literature however with regard to the effects of S epidermidis biofilm on phagocytic killing Killing by human macrophages et al and PMNs et al Kristian et al as well as killing by leukocytes et al are strongly attenuated in the presence of bacteria Figure Model of the host response to S epidermidis infections Breaching through the skin can result in S epidermidis dissemination into the bloodstream to cause bacteremia and acute cases of sepsis Host immunity against septic infections heavily depends on neutrophils complement as well as activation of PRRs including coupled receptors such as and infections on medical implants originate from contaminations during device insertion or in rare cases from the bloodstream Patients with medical implants are susceptible to S epidermidis sepsis as biofilm bacteria can often disseminate into the bloodstream The immune response to infections is generally thought to be not effective as biofilms inhibit phagocytic killing by PMNs and macrophages In addition they skew the immune system toward enhanced production of cytokines such as while limiting the secretion of cytokines including and The role of complement in CoNS infections is quite unclear While S epidermidis strains elicit a stronger response in the activation and release of complement components than their isogenic and thus counterparts et al Fredheim et al such complement release did not translate to enhanced phagocytic killing S epidermidis biofilms triggered release but protected S epidermidis from and IgG opsonization and killing et al some authors tried to attribute specific effects to PIA rather than biofilm formation by mechanically destroying aggregates et al in none of these studies a clear distinction between the effects of biofilm agglomerations and a direct effect of the exopolysaccharide PIA can be made As for the claimed properties of PIA et al Fredheim et al Ferreirinha et al the facts that PIA is a substance and isogenic mutants have distinctly different cell surface properties makes it difficult to attribute observed effects directly to the PIA molecule It has been reported that S epidermidis strains elicit production of rather than cytokines et al In the respective study primary human macrophages stimulated with live S epidermidis from biofilms produced lower levels of cytokines and elevated levels of the cytokine than planktonic cells grown for h Obviously in that comparison other factors such as most notably factors such as the modulins et al discussed below may be made responsible for the observed differences rather than biofilm formation itself However comparing with isogenic Embp or strains Schommer et al also observed a reduced inflammatory response in macrophages with reduced activation and reduced production et al Little is known about how the adaptive immune system responds to infections in part because it is difficult to establish S epidermidis biofilm infection models Vuong et al have developed a murine infection model with a S epidermidis bioluminescent strain called SE with which they were able to monitor in the progression of S epidermidis infection et al Comparing the susceptibility of Nu Nu and B to S epidermidis infection with Balb C mice the authors found that in particular the Nu Nu mice were more susceptible to infection indicating an important role of T immunity against S epidermidis infection Immunity against S epidermidis during sepsis The presence of CoNS in the blood often originating from the dispersal of bacteria from biofilms on indwelling medical devices can cause acute sepsis CoNS bacteremia is associated with significant healthcare costs morbidity and mortality and Wenzel and premature neonates are the most vulnerable to CoNS sepsis with S epidermidis being the most prevalent CoNS species involved and Otto In contrast to S epidermidis infections which are chronic S epidermidis sepsis is acute by nature Therefore the host immune response to S epidermidis sepsis which takes place largely in the bloodstream is quite different from that against S epidermidis biofilm Since neonates have increased susceptibility to S epidermidis sepsis most of the studies on the matter dealt with S epidermidis neonatal sepsis Therefore the following discussion will be focused on neonatal immunity in response to S epidermidis sepsis An important element in the innate immune response are innate immune cells among which neutrophils dominate in number Neutrophils recognize invading microbes via a repertoire of host receptors ingest them and eliminate them within the phagosome by reactive oxygen species and antimicrobial proteins released during a process called degranulation et al In addition lysed neutrophils can form neutrophil extracellular traps to bind and kill invading microbes et al Several pattern recognition receptors which recognize and bind to conserved microbial products molecular and play an essential role in the activation of the innate immune response have been shown to be critical in host immunity against S epidermidis sepsis was shown to be critical for clearance of S epidermidis in a mouse sepsis model et al In human neonates there is an increase in expression over the course of S epidermidis sepsis et al however a immune system was reported to be less proficient in eliciting multiple cytokine responses in neonates compared to adults et al S epidermidis PIA et al PSMs et al and lipoteichoic acid et al have been claimed to be effectors of However studies with PIA and PSMs were not verified with isogenic and as for LTA there has been recent evidence indicating that staphylococcal lipopeptides rather than LTA are the real agents et al Furthermore in S aureus it was shown that PSMs are not direct agonists of but lead to the release of lipopeptides from the cell surface and thus have a secondary effect et al an effect likely also present in S epidermidis Based on the fact that the formyl peptide receptor recognizes PSMs et al this G chemoattractant receptor is another potentially important host receptor in the response against S epidermidis As shown in S aureus activation induces chemotaxis granule exocytosis and release from PMNs et al Kretschmer et al Studies on the effects of PSMs of CoNS on the immune response have only been performed with pure PSMs of S epidermidis et al and so far have been hampered by the multitude of genetic psm loci in S epidermidis and the general difficulty to produce isogenic deletion mutants in CoNS However a recent study attributed a crucial role to the mobile highly produced of S epidermidis in inflammation and immune evasion using isogenic mutants et al Complement also plays an important role in the immunity against S epidermidis sepsis Deficiencies in complement factor and IgG are associated with a higher risk of neonatal sepsis et al Furthermore in a study using an sepsis model S epidermidis induced significantly lower complement activation in neonatal compared to adult blood et al This finding suggests that there is a maturational deficiency in the neonatal complement system which in part may explain why neonates are more susceptible to S epidermidis septic infections than adults Moreover this study highlights the importance of the complement system in the host defense against S epidermidis sepsis Like complement neutrophils of preterm neonates display maturational deficiency They show an impaired oxidative burst compared to those isolated from term newborns when stimulated with S epidermidis et al This in part may also explain the increased susceptibility in preterm neonates to S epidermidis sepsis Interestingly enough monocytes another cellular component in the innate immune response are not essential to the host defense against neonatal S epidermidis sepsis as both human neonatal and adult monocytes displayed similar phagocytic and intracellular killing capacity et al Taken together this indicates that neutrophils play a particularly important role in the immune response during S epidermidis sepsis While there are numerous studies dedicated to understanding the role of the innate immune response during S epidermidis sepsis research on the role of the adaptive immune response in S epidermidis septic infections remains limited As these infections are acute in nature it is unlikely that the adaptive immune response plays a significant role Accordingly intravenous transfer of immunoglobulin from donors with high titers of antibodies to S epidermidis or S aureus failed to protect from sepsis in preterm newborns et al DeJonge et al Conclusions CoNS infections and in particular S epidermidis pose a significant medical and economic burden to public healthcare Furthermore with the emergence of antibiotic resistance treatment options are becoming limited However the elimination of S epidermidis bacteria appears inappropriate as they are an integral part of the beneficial microbiota on the skin and mucous membranes The beneficial role of S epidermidis colonization in the prevention of pathogen overgrowth on the skin based on results in mice has been attributed to stimulation of the immune response However with the mouse skin model barely reflecting the situation on human skin it remains poorly understood whether the findings are transferable to humans Furthermore whether there is a role of potential direct bacterial interaction between S epidermidis and pathogens on the skin remains to be investigated The immune response to S epidermidis during infection possibly is even less well understood In chronic infection it is difficult to distinguish between effects of shear agglomeration and those mediated by specific cell surface components During sepsis the nature and role of cytokines and inflammation pathways in response to S epidermidis remains equally poorly defined Elucidation of these mechanisms will also provide more information on the question why neonates are particularly susceptible to S epidermidis infection Progress that has been made regarding molecular biology tools for S epidermidis and CoNS in general will be of great help in these endeavors and especially assist in differentiating between direct and secondary effects Clearly a deeper understanding of the host immune response to these infections will be critical to the development of S epidermidis vaccines and novel therapies Author contributions TN and MO wrote the manuscript MP and TN prepared figures Conflict of interest statement The authors declare that the research was conducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could be construed as a potential conflict of interest This study was supported by the Intramural Research Program of the in accordance with accepted academic practice No use distribution or reproduction is permitted which does not comply with these terms Malignant pleural mesothelioma is a highly aggressive tumor primarily associated with asbestos exposure Early detection of MPM is restricted by the long latency period until clinical presentation the ineffectiveness of imaging techniques in early stage detection and the lack of biomarkers with high sensitivity and specificity In this study we used transcriptome data mining in order to determine which CLAUDIN genes are differentially expressed in MPM as compared to controls Using the same approach we identified the interactome of the differentially expressed CLDN genes and assessed their expression profile Subsequently we evaluated the effect of tumor histology asbestos exposure deletion status and gender on the gene expression level of the claudin interactome We found that out of studied CLDNs and out of available interactors SHBG were differentially expressed in MPM specimens vs healthy tissues The genes encoding the and proteins present differences in their expression profile between the three histological subtypes of MPM Moreover is significantly in the cohort of patients with previous history of asbestos exposure was also found significantly underexpressed in patients lacking the gene These results warrant the detailed in vitro investigation of the role of in the pathobiology of MPM asbestos claudins interactome malignant mesothelioma pleura tight junctions transcriptome Introduction Malignant Pleural Mesothelioma is a highly aggressive tumor primarily associated with exposure to asbestos Due to the prolonged latent period between asbestos exposure and clinical presentation of the disease the incidence of MPM has continued to rise across Europe even after the imposed restrictions on asbestos use et al Worldwide the incidence of MPM is increasing and it is expected to peak in the years and Lake MPM diagnosis and treatment is challenging therefore current research efforts are focused in biomarker discovery that would aid its early diagnosis prognosis and therapeutic outcome prediction et al Transcriptome studies combined with data mining techniques have provided new insights into the pathogenesis of the disease and have led to the identification of new candidate biomarkers with potential clinical value et al Claudins represent a family of tetraspan transmembrane proteins that contribute to the formation and the proper function of tight junctions and Morin They regulate the paracellular transport of ions and molecules in a size and charge sensitive manner et al A notable feature of claudins is that some members increase the paracellular permeability while others decrease it More specifically and increase the paracellular cation permeability in the Tight Junctions whereas and have a sealing function et al Milatz et al Soini In addition to their contribution to the establishment of cellular polarity the TJ proteins also participate in the regulation of cell differentiation and proliferation et al and Morin Soini The pleural mesothelial cells form a monolayer that expresses claudins in their TJs although their exact role in the pleural physiology and pathophysiology is scarcely investigated et al Currently it is known that mesothelial TJ claudins contribute to the pleural membrane permeability while during inflammation the expression levels of claudins change leading to increased pleural permeability et al Markov and Amasheh These data highlight the role of claudins and TJ related proteins in the context of pleural physiology and pathophysiology Several studies have highlighted the role of claudins in cancer since in several malignancies kidney breast stomach instestine pancreas and their expression is deregulated et al Furthermore accumulating data suggest roles for claudins in tumor development and progression as well as in signal transduction while in several cancers expression of claudins is associated with prognosis et al Claudins have also been studied in the context of MPM by means of immunohistochemistry et al et al In this aspect several changes in the expression of claudins have been documented and Ahmed Soini Most studies so far have focused on the diagnostic value of claudins notably claudins in distinguishing MPM from other carcinomas has been shown to be highly effective in the differential diagnosis between MPM and metastatic carcinomas et al b Ohta et al Jo et al However at the transcriptional level there is scarcity of information regarding the differential gene expression of claudins between healthy and MPM samples In this study we applied data mining and transcriptomic analysis in order to determine the CLAUDIN CLDN genes that are differentially expressed in MPM specimens as compared to healthy controls Using the same approach we also probed for CLDN interactors and assessed their expression patterns so as to identify novel genes interacting with CLDNs that may contribute to the pathophysiology of MPM Finally we evaluated the effect of MPM histology asbestos exposure deletion status and gender on the gene expression level of the claudin interactome Materials and methods Identification of the differential gene expression profile of CLDNs in microarray data from MPM and control counterparts We used gene expression data from an MPM study included in the Oncomine Research Premium Edition Cancer Microarray database http www oncomine org in order to in MPM specimens as compared to healthy ones The genes that were not assessed in GDS were CLDNs In order to ensure that the data were generated with the same methodology we selected gene expression data were downloaded from Oncomine in Excel format and were scrutinized selecting only the ones referring to surgically excised samples excluding the ones referring to mesothelial and MPM cell lines Finally in this study there were n MPM cases and n controls n pleura and n lung The gene expression data were log transformed median centered per array and the standard deviation was normalized to one per array as described previously et al All values from the transformed data were downloaded from Oncomine during March Identification of the interactome of the differentially expressed claudins The gene interaction network of the significantly differentially expressed CLDNs in MPM patients was constructed using http thebiogrid org ConsensusPathDB http cpdb molgen mpg de and String http org databases The database is a repository of genetic and interactions that are curated from the primary biomedical literature for all major model organism species et al The ConsensusPathDB database integrates interaction networks including binary and complex genetic metabolic signaling gene regulatory and interactions as well as biochemical pathways et al String is a database of known and predicted protein interactions including both direct and indirect associations et al After querying for each differentially expressed CLDN in the above databases we superimposed the results in order Discussion MPM is a highly aggressive tumor arising from the mesothelial cells that line the pleural cavity et al Due to the established cause and effect relationship between asbestos exposure and MPM development researchers seek to identify suitable biomarkers for screening asbestos exposed populations and for early diagnosis while avoiding false positive results and unnecessary invasive procedures et al Although several studies have pointed to the effectiveness of soluble mesothelin as a biomarker with high specificity its limited sensitivity confines its use as a screening tool for the asymptomatic cohorts et al Thus at the present time there are no biomarkers in widespread clinical use for MPM et al Transcript profiling along with new and bioinformatics have been extensively used in the field of personalized medicine enabling researchers to identify biomarkers for cancer screening diagnosis and prognosis et al In this study we used established data mining techniques through which we have already reported and to be ideal candidates for further study in MPM pathophysiology et al Tasiopoulou et al Vavougios et al Claudins are structural molecules of TJs present in epithelial endothelial and mesothelial cells et al Soini The patterns of claudin expression within TJs are distinctly diverse among different tissues accounting for the observed differences in permeability and electrical resistance of various epithelia et al Markov et al It should be noted that not only the expression of claudin family members but also their localization within cells may vary et al Dittmann et al The latter might be affected by several exogenous factors such as food components plant compounds and microbial toxins et al Markov et al Differential gene expression of claudins has been reported in several tumors depending on the exact claudin and cancer studied et al Chao et al and Morin et al Valle and Morin Davidson Soini Here we report that is significantly in MPM patients as compared to controls while CLDNs and are significantly An in vitro study using and cell lines et al has shown by means of immunohistochemistry and immunoblotting a high level of claudin in both cell lines as opposed to claudins and An earlier study demonstrated by means of immunohistochemistry that in MPM there was a lower expression of and than in metastatic adenocarcinomas of the pleura suggesting that they could serve as differential diagnostic markers et al In the same report PMCs showed expression of claudin but no expression was found for and Two more studies assessing the expression of in a large series of normal and MPM tissues by immunohistochemistry reported that is a definitive negative marker for MPM which is in agreement with our data showing the significant of in MPM as opposed to controls et al b This finding has been consistently shown in other studies as well et al Jo et al Finally one more study has demonstrated that the gene expression of and was significantly lower in malignant peritoneal mesothelioma as compared to ovarian carcinomas et al In our study we also demonstrate that the gene is significantly in the epithelioid histological subtype of MPM as compared to the sarcomatoid and biphasic phenotypes Similar results were shown in diffuse malignant peritoneal mesothelioma at the protein level et al On the contrary we observed that the gene expression of is significantly increased in sarcomatoid MPM as compared to epithelioid MPM has been reported as a useful biomarker in assessing tumor load stage and prognosis for patients with malignant melanoma et al It has been suggested that the differences in the molecular biology of epithelioid and MPM may contribute to differences in their clinical behavior et al The epithelioid cell type is among the factors that favor the overall survival of MPM patients et al Musk et al Linton et al As a consequence it has been proposed that the diagnosis of the sarcomatoid variant on a biopsy should preclude radical surgery and therapy should aim at symptoms management and preservation of quality of life et al Therefore the clear distinction of histological subtypes could direct clinicians to the appropriate treatment options In the literature it is supported that the current golden standard for MPM diagnosis is a combination of two positive and two negative immunohistochemical markers in the epithelioid and biphasic type but sarcomatous type do not have specific markers making diagnosis more difficult et al Here we propose that and could serve as complementary diagnostic tools and should be further investigated Next we observed that was in patients lacking the gene Moreover the gene was significantly in MPM patients with previous history of asbestos exposure compared to the unexposed ones is the most frequently inactivated tumor suppressor gene in human MPM The inactivation of both and Arf products of the gene has been suggested to act synergistically in accelerating tumorigenesis in vivo Development of MPM is strongly associated with asbestos exposure with of the patients having previous exposure to asbestos fibers and Lake Nakano Sekido A significant association has been described between increasing number of methylated cell cycle control genes and asbestos burden This finding was followed by the observation that quantitative measure of asbestos exposure was associated with over discrete CpG loci and that in of cases there was increased methylation associated with increased exposure and Marsit The correlation between methylation status and extended exposure to asbestos was also confirmed by Fujii et al Likewise the results of this study are indicative of the epigenetic effect of asbestos in the transcriptional level of the gene suggesting its potential utility as a screening biomarker for populations at risk Although in our analysis with respect to gender the gene expression of SHBG and was not different between sexes we observed that the SHBG gene which encodes the Sex Globulin was in MPM patients as compared to healthy controls SHBG is a major regulator of free plasma androgens and also mediates androgen and estrogen signaling at the cell membrane via cyclic adenosine monophosphate and Schleutker It is generally accepted that although MPM is less common in women compared to men female MPM patients survive longer et al Musk et al Linton et al Taioli et al It has been proposed that differences in asbestos exposure tumor biology and the impact of circulating hormones on host response must be investigated to understand this survival advantage and improve prognosis for patients of both genders et al The observed of the SHBG gene in the group of MPM patients relative to the control group advocates the role of sex hormones in the pathogenesis and prognosis of the disease This is stressed out by a study showing that estrogen receptor beta acts as a tumor suppressor of high potential relevance to prediction of disease progression and to therapeutic response in MPM patients et al As in the case of SHBG the genes encoding and were found significantly in MPM specimens as compared to their healthy counterparts The protein product of interacts with its target proteins within cells to regulate enzyme activities cell growth differentiation and Ca homeostasis et al It is thought that expression levels of individual family proteins vary considerably in different tumors and with respect to cancer progression and Einarsson or is a proinflammatory chemokine involved in the promotion of neutrophil chemotaxis and degranulation and Wilson It has been demonstrated that many types of human carcinomas express high levels of relative to normal tissues et al In addition high serum levels of this chemokine correlate with disease progression and poor prognosis while a link exists between tumor transition and tumor stemness et al Gales et al In this study gene was found in the group of MPM patients compared to the control group It has been demonstrated that neutrophil infiltration into the pleural space is a characteristic feature of an early and acute inflammatory response in several pleural diseases and that activated PMCs secrete in a polarized fashion et al Inhibition of has been shown to reduce human MPM propagation in a nude mouse model et al Asbestos directly features of EMT at various stages of tumor development et al Vascular endothelial cadherin an endothelial specific adhesion molecule plays a pivotal role in the formation maturation and remodeling of the vascular wall It has been shown that directly enhances the expression level of by tethering repressive transcription factors away from the CLDN promoter Conversely the absence of functional is associated with loss of expression et al Gavard These results suggest that any changes in will impact the endothelial barrier function at multiple levels and also explain why inhibition may cause a marked increase in permeability and Gutkind Taddei et al Increased permeability is an early step in the angiogenic process enabling endothelial migration out of the primary vessel in order to begin formation of the tumor neovasculature Guelte et al On the other hand it has been demonstrated that induction of during EMT promotes breast cancer progression via signaling indicating that in certain tumor cells can induce cellular responses that are in contrast to its role in contact growth inhibition in endothelial cells et al Thus there are two distinct functions of both in angiogenesis and progression of cancer et al Regarding thoracic tumors in particular it has been reported that may be an interesting marker for analysis in therapeutic trials although results from clinical studies are pending et al An important limitation of our findings is the lack of information regarding the asbestos exposure history of the MPM patients of the Gordon Mesothelioma study If these data were available we could assess asbestos induced gene expression changes between MPM patients and controls Our results require further investigation in the clinical setting with the inclusion of a large series of MPM patients vs healthy asbestos exposed individuals serving as controls Moreover detailed information regarding the duration of asbestos exposure and the type of exposure should also be incorporated in future research Conclusions The results of this study are suggestive of a distinct gene expression profile of the claudin interactome in MPM and underline the epigenetic effect of asbestos on the transcriptional level of the gene The role of and in pleural physiology and pathophysiology is unknown and requires in depth investigation at the functional level Additionally both and should be further investigated as gene biomarkers in MPM with respect to their potential to discriminate the histological MPM subgroups at the molecular level and thus provide tools for personalized accepted academic practice No use distribution or reproduction is permitted which does not comply with these terms The role of reactive oxygen species in microbial metabolism and stress response has emerged as a major theme in microbiology and infectious disease Reactive fluorescent dyes have the potential to advance the study of ROS in the complex intracellular environment especially for and analyses However current approaches to measuring intracellular ROS have the potential for significant artifacts Here we describe a robust platform for flow cytometric quantification of ROS in bacteria using fluorescent dyes with ROS measurements in of individual cells under a variety of conditions False positives and variability among sample types g bacterial species stress are reduced with a flexible gating scheme that accounts for and light background fluorescence DNA content and dye uptake to identify cells producing ROS Using CellROX Green dye with Escherichia coli Mycobacterium smegmatis and Mycobacterium bovis BCG as diverse model bacteria we show that the generation of a quantifiable CellROX Green signal for superoxide but not hydrogen hydroxyl radicals validates this dye as a superoxide the level of superoxide does not correlate with cytotoxicity or antibiotic the antibiotic tolerant state of mycobacteria is associated with high levels of and production of superoxide is idiosyncratic with regard to both the species and the physiological state of the bacteria We also show that the gating method is applicable to other fluorescent indicator dyes such as the diacetate acetoxymethyl ester and tetrazolium chloride for cellular esterase and reductive respiratory activities respectively These results demonstrate that properly controlled flow cytometry coupled with fluorescent probes provides precise and accurate quantitative analysis of ROS generation and metabolic changes in stressed bacteria reactive oxygen species flow cytometry bacteria oxidative stress starvation antibiotics Alliance for Research and Technology Centre Introduction Reactive oxygen species have been proposed to play critical roles in microbial metabolism Imlay and response to environmental stressors such as antibiotic exposure Brynildsen et al Zhao and Drlica Though are often viewed as a single agent the widely differing chemistry of specific types of ROS critically determines their function in microbes Among the biologically relevant ROS superoxide is a relatively unreactive species arising from electron transport processes and cytochrome activity and is detoxified by superoxide dismutases to the relatively inert hydrogen peroxide O Hassan and Fridovich Iyanagi Dedon and Tannenbaum Reduction of H O by metals g Fe Fe and Cu Cu in Fenton yields highly reactive hydroxyl radicals Imlay et al Imlay Bataineh et al Though less abundant in bacteria another source of hydroxyl radicals involves homolytic scission of peroxynitrite t arising from the reaction of nitric oxide and O Dedon and Tannenbaum The recent emergence of fluorescent probes to detect ROS builds on the use of fluorescent dyes to study bacterial components such as nucleic acid abundance or dehydrogenase activity Walberg et al et al In bacteria fluorescent probes have been most widely used in attempts to define the role of ROS production in response to antibiotic exposures Albesa et al Goswami et al Kohanski et al Wang et al Dwyer et al A variety of fluorescent ROS probes are now available with each probe claiming to possess different reactivity stability fluorescence and membrane transport properties Kalyanaraman et al Imlay However the efficiency and specificity of different dyes for detecting different ROS in vivo have rarely been established with any confidence Kalyanaraman et al much less across a range of different bacteria Among other dyes bacterial ROS have often been studied using p fluorescein Kohanski et al Dwyer et al and or diacetate Roca and Ramakrishnan Dwyer et al The latter is prone to signal artifacts due to erroneous amplification of the fluorescence intensity by a mechanism involving an intermediate radical Kalyanaraman et al This problem has led several groups to use HPF for ROS analysis in bacteria Kohanski et al Nguyen et al Dwyer et al Grant et al but HPF almost exclusively detects such as hydroxyl radical and hypochlorous acid Setsukinai et al While there is emerging evidence for involvement of ROS in stress in a limited range of model bacteria mainly Escherichia coli recent studies have challenged the generality of ROS production on the basis of the low dynamic range of HPF Renggli et al and problems with spurious fluorescent signals and other artifacts Keren et al Liu and Imlay Renggli et al Paulander et al There are other factors that complicate the use of dyes Among these are the uptake and removal of both unreacted and dye molecules from the cells by efflux pumps increased membrane permeability caused by cellular stress Renggli et al as well as poorly defined bacterial metabolic states at the time of the stress and dye staining For example while E coli does not possess cytochrome mycobacteria have dozens McLean et al Ouellet et al with as sources of O Munro et al The difficulty of measuring ROS coupled with these idiosyncratic factors in individual bacteria and across different bacterial species have hindered a broader examination of cell state as a factor in ROS generation and its role in the decision between cell death and survival To overcome these problems we developed a robust platform for flow cytometric detection of ROS in bacteria using a stable fluorescent dye This standardized approach employs a gating scheme to account for and light DNA content and dye uptake to accurately identify and quantify cells The method accounts for autofluorescence arising from changes in cell morphology membrane composition and protein expression during normal cell growth and the cellular response to stresses such as antibiotic treatment and starvation Kim et al Renggli et al Paulander et al We piloted this method with CellROX Green dye to assess its activity in living bacteria and to assess claims Choi et al that CellROX Green is selective for O in bacterial cells There are many methods for detecting O including electrochemistry spectroscopy chemiluminescence and vibrational spectroscopy Hayyan et al though intracellular O has traditionally been quantified by extracellular reduction of ferricytochrome c or by electron with spin trapping by N Frejaville et al Huycke et al Korshunov and Imlay Neither of these bulk measurements provide resolution of endogenous O in bacterial populations Though new probes specific to O and suitable for direct in vivo studies have been developed in recent years they have not been evaluated in bacteria Mukhopadhyay et al Hu et al Shin et al Here we applied our flow cytometric method with CellROX Green to quantify O production in three diverse but model bacteria E coli and the mycobacterial species Mycobacterium smegmatis and Mycobacterium bovis bacille all subjected to the stresses of antibiotic exposure and nutrient depletion We found that changes in O production across isogenic bacterial populations are heterogeneous and highly dependent upon the nature of the stress and the physiological state of the cells We also demonstrate the utility of the method for two other fluorescent dyes diacetate acetoxymethyl ester for esterase activity Schreer et al and tetrazolium chloride for cellular respiratory activity Rodriguez et al Materials and Methods Bacteria Strains and Culture Mycobacterium smegmatis mc was plated on agar supplemented with Middlebrook Oleic Albumin Dextrose Catalase growth Method for Quantification of Bacterial ROS Using Fluorescent Dyes The availability of fluorescent dyes for the detection and quantification of reactive chemical species in cells has fostered the development of analyses in microbiology and antibiotic pharmacology including both population assays and flow cytometry assays However factors such as dye uptake efficiency dye efflux changes in cell morphology and background fluorescence complicate the application of these fluorescent assays to bacteria and confound the interpretation of observed changes in fluorescence To achieve assay precision and accuracy and ensure credible and biologically meaningful results we developed a gating scheme Figures B to select for particle size based on FSC and SSC as light passes through the cells DNA content based on DAPI staining other the presence of dye based on fluorescence above unstained and particles and dye reactivity above baseline or basal fluorescence Application of this flow cytometry method distinguishes bacteria from debris by selecting for size and DNA content which also distinguishes single cells from dividing cells and individual bacterial species in mixed cultures Additionally greater sensitivity and specificity for ROS and metabolic activity is achieved by removing contributions from autofluorescence and by selecting only cells that have taken up the dye with of those cells for highly fluorescent activated dye Here we illustrate this scheme with CellROX hi gating for endogenous ROS quantification Figure and then demonstrate the versatility of the assay with examples using CTC and CFDA dyes for cellular metabolism Figures D FIGURE Optimization of gating and other flow cytometric parameters minimizes artifacts in reactive oxygen species detection with fluorescent probes in bacteria Workflow diagram summarizing the flow cytometry gating strategy Step selects for and particles Step excludes particles that do not contain DNA Step accounts for background fluorescence by eliminating cells that did not take up the dye and cells with autofluorescence Step quantifies dye activation The gating process and rationale is further elaborated in analysis scheme Figures B defines the bacterial population of interest based on FSC and SSC properties In addition Step gating can be adjusted for populations in which a significant portion exhibits changes in cell morphology By considering increases in fluorescence observed in cells with elevated SSC or FSC which can be performed by gating such as SSC versus fluorescence these cells can be selected for analysis if they pass the subsequent gates for background fluorescence be considered Dye and then for desired activation of the fluorescent dye Each bacterial cell has morphological and biological properties that may be uniquely altered in response to stress or as part of its life cycle Gating e SSC and FSC in Step allows consistent selection for cell size shape complexity and composition For example during logarithmic growth SSC and FSC profiles of filamentous E coli differ from those of M smegmatis bacilli Figure Overall both bacilli and filamentous bacteria have higher FSC signals during cell division At the same time population heterogeneity in cell size or length and cellular macromolecular composition can be detected by FSC and SSC respectively For M smegmatis heterogeneity is likely due to bacterial replication on the basis of time rather than cell size Aldridge et al Depending upon cytometer settings bacteria passing through the light source at different angles will be detected as lower or higher FSC SSC signals than those observed for uniform spheres Additionally stresses such as antibiotic exposures can alter cell light scatter by inhibiting replication or altering cell morphology such as by causing filamentation or by inhibiting septation Figure Renggli et al Paulander et al et al These differences in morphology and composition detected by FSC and SSC should be considered when interpreting bacterial populations during an analysis since these changes can significantly alter the observed fluorescence Step ensures that only cells with intact DNA are included in the analysis Small particles such as cell debris and dust particles also generate FSC and SSC signals Therefore DNA content staining is used to differentiate bacteria from particles This staining step further enables the assessment of several biologically relevant parameters including detection of doubling cells cell aggregates and dead cells with fragmented DNA et al The gating also excludes artifacts from the analysis which may arise from an abundance of dead cell debris in studies of bacterial persistence and dormancy as pursued here with M smegmatis For example subsequent experiments in Figures show that of the mycobacteria were killed by antibiotics before a population was established with the debris potentially confounding flow cytometry analysis Step accounts for background fluorescence and helps to distinguish cells that take up dye molecules from those that do not thus increasing the accuracy and rigor of the ROS analysis Here the relatively weak but detectable fluorescence of unactivated dye is exploited to select all presumptive cells by virtue of their fluorescence above that of unstained cells This fluorescence of unactivated CellROX Green is apparent as a increase in fluorescence in PBS solutions above the PBS background versus f u under conditions used in the flow and by a increase in fluorescence when CellROX Green is added to or cells upon fluorimeter settings and cell It is important to note that flow cytometry cannot be used to accurately attribute the source of increased fluorescence unstained to specific changes in cellular morphology composition and metabolism ROS generation or increased dye uptake However using this gate for dye uptake increases the accuracy for events in the assay In the absence of this step all cells from Steps and will be analyzed regardless of dye uptake status Only after gating for size DNA and dye presence is it possible to accurately identify cells in which ROS has potentially activated the dye molecules to fluoresce above background levels and to quantify the fluorescence intensities of these cells It is important to point out that Step also accounts for changes in background fluorescence from a variety of sources For example in our hands the exponential growth in the presence of LB or cell culture medium during staining of E coli and M smegmatis respectively increased background signals by up to Increases in fluorescence were also observed in and bacteria Figure As dead cells do not have metabolic processes such fluorescence increases indicate that ungated fluorescent signals cannot be entirely attributed to the presence of ROS In these cases variation in the background fluorescence makes it difficult to determine whether the summed fluorescence increment above that observed in unstained cells is due to activated dye that reacted with ROS produced in metabolically active cells by unreacted dye taken up by cells or by fluorescent intracellular compounds such as flavins Benson et al The Dye gating in Step minimizes this issue by cells that possess fluorescence greater than unstained cells which includes cells that have internalized dye insoluble upon reaction which results in strong fluorescence from activated dye molecules retained within the cells while the fluorescent carboxyfluoroscein product of is negatively charged and thus retained within cells longer than fluorescein This positive attribute is similar to the activity of CellRox Green CellROX Green is a Sensitive Detector of Superoxide but not H O ROS In addition to quantifying ROS identifying the ROS species generated during stress is a crucial step in establishing the precise molecular mechanisms underlying the stress response The challenge here is that the reactivity of individual fluorescent probes for specific ROS has not been clearly defined under biological conditions and many probes react with a variety of oxidants and free radical species We chose to use CellROX Green as an ROS probe due to its unique feature of having high fluorescence quantum yields only upon and binding to dsDNA Invitrogen This feature obviates artifacts due to altered membrane integrity resulting from stress or cell state and enhances accumulation of dye to maximize fluorescence signal intensity above background and autofluorescence in cells critical to setting the Dye gate in Step However for this probe especially there is a lack of clarity in the scientific community about its intracellular ROS specificity ResearchGate Choi et al and to our knowledge there is no consensus on its reactivity in bacterial cells CellROX Green is a propriety photostable dye which according to the manufacturer exhibits ROS reactivity that complements HPF Unlike HPF CellROX Green reacts with hydroxyl radicals O and t in vitro but not with H O NO ONOO or HOCl Invitrogen However CellROX Green has recently been claimed to react almost exclusively with O in vivo Choi et al Hence we sought to confirm the identity of the intracellular ROS detected by CellROX Green in bacteria using two ROS generators menadione a quinone that undergoes catalytic redox cycling to reduce molecular oxygen to O Hassan and Fridovich Iyanagi and H O that reacts with metals to produce extremely ferryl or hydroxyl radicals under specific conditions Imlay et al Imlay Bataineh et al CellROX Green associated killing is both and cell Discussion The use of fluorescent probes combined with flow cytometry is a powerful approach to investigate biological processes within single cells as well as in cell populations We developed a gating strategy to minimize false positive signals and artifacts by accounting for DNA content changes in cell morphology dye uptake and retention and target specific dye activation in bacterial cells This approach is generally applicable to intracellular metabolic probes as illustrated here with CellROX Green CTC and With specific application to CellROX Green the flow cytometry method provides quantitative measurement of light scatter and fluorescence emission by this O fluorescent probe thus allowing measurement of O in of individual cells within a sample in addition to the population abundance The gating scheme presented here makes use of several gating strategies for mammalian cells and systematically applies them to bacteria at each of the four steps The basis for Step is the selection of the cell population of interest based on scatter properties such as when selecting for lymphocytes versus monocytes or granulocytes Although commonly used in environmental microbiology scatter properties of bacteria have not been considered in ROS studies DNA content staining as in Step although not absolutely necessary strengthens the precision and accuracy of the data by distinguishing bacteria from particles of similar sizes It also provides an additional parameter for analysis along with FSC and SSC which together can distinguish different bacteria or bacteria in different cell states Muller and Finally DNA content gives information about life cycle stages within the population that may provide insight into stress response mechanisms While large aggregates and dramatic filamentation would be excluded in our plots due to the flow cytometer settings for FSC particles um are collected during the gating scheme does not necessarily ignore elongated cells and instead accounts for their elongation By taking into account increases in fluorescence observed in cells with higher SSC or FSC by gating such as SSC versus cells with increased SSC or FSC can be selected for analysis if they pass the subsequent gates for increases in green fluorescence to be considered Dye and then CellROX hi This gating procedure normalizes for changes in SSC by not using flat cutoffs as in histograms g at fluorescence of If one does see two distinct populations of cells separate size gates or DNA content gates can be made for each population followed by consistent gating for green fluorescence The changes in background green fluorescence are not the same magnitude as activated CellROX Green dye so generation of ROS in cells with high background staining should be distinguishable using unstained and stained treated cells Together Steps and of the gating scheme select for probe fluorescence inside cells which validates the location of the probe reaction with ROS Step selects all cells with fluorescence above controls This basal fluorescence must be considered a conservative baseline signal that accounts for detection of unreacted reacted or degraded dye in the cell or less likely adhering to the cell surface as well as fluorescence from intracellular components Considering that culture conditions bacterial species and stress can affect dye permeability in some bacteria Walberg et al an assessment of dye content in each cell becomes important whenever possible The point of gating Step is a conservative one to minimize noise and artifacts by including in the analysis only cells that appear to have taken up a dye molecule By setting the selection threshold for Step above these basal levels Step selects cells with a high probability of containing an dye molecule It is important to use the Dye gate as the denominator for determining positive ROS signals as different stress treatments change the basal fluorescence There are several advantages to this a gating flow cytometry method ROS in bacterial populations have been evaluated with fluorescent dyes using plate readers or by measuring mean fluorescence intensity in total cell populations collected using a flow cytometer Kohanski et al Nguyen et al Dwyer et al However the problem with these approaches is that depending upon the gating of the flow cytometer data the use of controls and rigorous characterization of the dye sensitivity and specificity these fluorescence methods can yield false positives due to background fluorescence from the dye or the treatment as reported previously and observed in the present studies Renggli et al Paulander et al Plate reader data also suffers from artifacts of extracellular fluorescence Moreover mean or median changes in fluorescence in total populations may reflect a small proportion of cells producing high levels of ROS or a large proportion generating low to moderate amounts of ROS Given evidence for the intracellular ROS concentration as a determinant of cellular responses to specific antibiotics Brynildsen et al the ability to both identify ROS and measure ROS abundance at the single cell level is vital to understanding mechanisms of cellular responses The strategy presented here for detection of ROS with a flow cytometer combined with rigorous gating of populations allows for determination of relative abundance of ROS generation within single cells One of the advantages of using CellROX Green activation as a O index in bacteria involves retention of activated dye in cells by binding to DNA which prevents loss of activated probe through efflux pumps or leakage through damaged cell membranes In terms of the chemical identify of the ROS species detected by CellROX Green we conclude that this dye selectively detects O in bacterial populations under a variety of environmental conditions and exposures Our results with menadione exposure and SOD mutant strains are consistent with published studies pointing to CellROX Green specificity for O in bacterial cells Choi et al We cannot rule out dye activation by RNS such as peroxynitrite the reaction product of NO and O which decays to generate nitrogen dioxide radical NO and hydroxyl radical Dedon and Tannenbaum However it is unlikely that even with high O levels there would be significant ONOO formation in bacteria under the exposure conditions used here The relative insignificance of hydroxyl radicals generated from ONOO is further emphasized by the fact that even high concentrations of H O which is to react with reducing metals to generate cytotoxic hydroxyl radicals or equivalently reactive ferryl radicals Imlay et al Imlay did not produce detectable activation of CellROX Green This points to either a relative insensitivity of the dye to hydroxyl radicals in vivo or to production of significantly lower levels of hydroxyl radicals relative to O in the cells H O can also lead to indirect ROS and RNS production in cells by activating transcription factors such as OxyR and PerR in bacteria to remodel cell metabolism and energetics with resulting increases in O and other radical species Marinho et al Again the lack of H O CellROX Green activation rules out such a mechanism H O metabolic remodeling may explain the activation of CellROX Green in H O human cells Segard et al However our studies reveal a lack of ROS species in bacteria exposed to levels of H O Clearly the interpretation of studies using H O as a calibrant in studies of ROS generation should be approached with caution The results of our studies with E coli and M smegmatis reveal several types of heterogeneity and idiosyncrasy in the bacterial ROS responses to chemical stimuli which warrant customization of the ROS method and caution in interpreting the results For example both types of bacteria showed different responses to menadione as a population in fluorescence histograms Figures D With increasing menadione exposures a increase in size of the CellROX hi M smegmatis was observed However there was no change in the population distribution as demonstrated by the absence of any change in the mean median or mode fluorescence intensity Figure In contrast two distinct populations emerged during menadione stress for E coli This change in population distribution was most evident at high menadione concentrations when a significant increase in the mean median and mode fluorescence intensity between low and high menadione exposures was observed Figure While we do not have a mechanistic explanation for this behavior we note that it is a consistent and reproducible shift in the size of the CellROX hi subpopulation in response to menadione indicating O stress It cannot be ruled out however that in longer exposures to menadione further fluorescence shifts in the population of both E coli and M smegmatis would occur However under current conditions the two bacteria both produce CellROX ROS but with different staining patterns These differences between E coli and M smegmatis suggest caution in extrapolating ROS results across bacterial species and genera In some cases it is not even possible to compare across different types of bacteria to due dye accessibility problems We shared the same problem experienced by Grant et al that HPF could not be used to detect ROS in M smegmatis even though it works with E coli This same caution in interpreting the results of ROS dye signals and extrapolating results across species must be applied to studies of antibiotic pharmacodynamics While fluorescent probes have been used to explore ROS generation caused by antibiotic exposure Kohanski et al Nguyen et al Dwyer et al Grant et al there is no unifying mechanistic model to explain why ROS are generated with specific antibiotics in some bacterial species but not others and more importantly which type of ROS is generated Our findings with CellROX Green in M smegmatis and E coli under the variety of conditions that cause increases in ROS lead us to conclude that O generation is not a universal feature of antibiotic stress does not distinguish bactericidal from bacteriostatic antibiotics and is not generally predictive of cell death Figure Rather our data suggest that ROS production is dependent on the physiological state of the cell specifically on changes in metabolism Previous studies of ROS metabolism in antibiotic tolerant bacteria revealed clear differences in the interaction Nguyen et al Maisonneuve and Gerdes Similarly our observation of O production during rifampicin treatment may be related to enzyme induction and metabolism as the antibiotic is a potent inducer of human cytochrome enzymes most notably and subfamily Madan et al This suggests that rifampicin may also induce CYPs in mycobacteria Niemi et al Since CYP activity is to generate high levels of O Denisov et al Munro et al our observation of CellROX Green activation in both and starved bacilli following rifampicin exposure Figures is consistent with previous studies showing transcriptional of different CYPs in mycobacteria following exposure to a variety of antibiotics Boshoff et al Indeed recently released microarray datasets for transcriptional response to antibacterial agents in the closely related human pathogen M tuberculosis shows that several CYPs including and are upregulated in response to rifampicin Gene Ontology Omnibus Accession The presence of elevated basal ROS levels in starved mycobacteria might suggest a vulnerability in light of evidence that potentiate existing ROS to promote bacterial cell death Brynildsen et al Dwyer et al Adolfsen and Brynildsen Belenky et al However our observations in mycobacteria do not support this as a universal model For instance the mycobacteria generated through nutrient deprivation have elevated O Figure yet are significantly resistant to four tuberculosis antibiotics Figures While endogenous ROS production has been correlated with antibiotic killing in some cases Brynildsen et al Dwyer et al increases in intracellular O levels in starved mycobacteria failed to potentiate the activities of several antibiotics This observation also raises concerns about the conclusion that the O tuberculosis antibiotic clofazimine which also binds tightly to DNA and RNA facilitates killing of persistent M smegmatis by virtue of O production Grant et al It is possible that cytotoxic activity involves tight binding of its reduced free radical form to DNA and RNA as demonstrated for the parent compound Morrison and Marley to create covalent adducts In any event our results demonstrate that O is unlikely to be the cause of toxicity in persistent or mycobacteria Finally we address the impact of potential heterogeneity in what appears to be changes in uptake of dye molecules into individual cells This issue becomes apparent for example in the increased proportion of cells appearing in the Dye gate following menadione treatment Figure which correlates with the proportion of cells with a fluorescence signal greater than untreated cells hi Figures C What appears to be a increase in the number of cells taking up dye raises the concerns that an increased CellROX hi signal could occur in spite of constant ROS levels dye molecules to or as a result of a large influx of unactivated weakly fluorescent parent dye molecules It is important to point out that the flow cytometry method is limited in its ability to precisely quantify the contribution of increases in dye uptake of individual cells such as increased permeability to CellROX Green or reduced efflux of the dye However the nature of the gating strategy the cell permeability and spectroscopic properties of the fluorescent dye and our observations of membrane permeability changes using PI argue that increases in CellROX Green fluorescence are truly due to increases in O levels in the cells First the Dye gate precedes CellROX hi gating so the latter is a subset of the former and in a rising tide argument increases in the Dye population will naturally accompany increases in the CellROX hi population The Dye gate of increased fluorescence above unstained cells is intended to be a conservative barrier to rule out artifacts so it is possible that untreated cells taking up smaller amounts of the weakly fluorescent dye will be gated out of the analysis for the sake of accuracy at the cost of sensitivity while increases in ROS levels in treated cells will raise the fluorescence of these previously missed cells above the threshold for Dye Second our analysis of antibiotic exposure and ROS in Figure revealed that there is no correlation between changes in membrane permeability and the magnitude of the CellROX hi signal ETM caused the highest CellROX Green fluorescence Figures C and the lowest membrane damage Figures F Third CellROX Green is a dye so its concentration should equilibrate between bulk solvent and cell interior The spectroscopic properties of CellROX Green imply that very high levels of unactivated dye must accumulate in a cell to produce a signal that rivals the magnitude of dye Assuming that CellROX Green has spectral properties roughly similar to HPF then both molar absorptivity and quantum efficiency are greatly increased by ROS activation and respectively Setsukinai et al This implies that an approximately increase in intracellular CellROX Green concentration would be needed to produce the equivalent of a increase in CellROX Green fluorescence above the mean median or fluorescence of the population The additional requirement for DNA binding to achieve the enhanced fluorescence by CellROX Green Invitrogen further reduces the likelihood that unactivated dye could account for changes in CellROX hi This is also consistent with the observation by Choi et al that permeabilization of the E coli cell membrane wall by Triton did not alter CellROX Green fluorescence Finally if the increased fluorescence in cells were simply due to increased dye concentration then there would not be multiple distinct cell populations observed on the flow cytometer g Figure All of this evidence rules out and changes in dye uptake as the basis for increased CellROX hi detection of ROS Taken together the results of our studies demonstrate that properly controlled flow cytometry coupled with fluorescent probes provides precise and accurate quantitative analysis of ROS generation and metabolic changes in stressed bacteria The gating strategy provides for a consistent comparison based on specific parameters across multiple samples in spite of changes in cellular morphology or background fluorescence Application of this method with CellROX Green and diverse bacteria reveals that superoxide generation arises idiosyncratically due to transient or phenotypic alterations in cell physiology caused by environmental or chemical stresses and is itself not a primary driver of bacterial death Author Contributions MM YC MS and PD designed experiments MM YC MS PH and MC performed experiments MM YC MS PH and MC analyzed data MM YC MS PH and PD wrote the manuscript MM
