Garrison Catherine E Gibson Daniel J Lin Yingxi Graybiel Ann M Department of Brain and Cognitive Sciences McGovern Institute for Brain Research Massachusetts Institute of Technology Cambridge MA USA Edited by Fumino Fujiyama Doshisha University Japan Reviewed by Heinz Steiner Rosalind Franklin University of Medicine and Science Tetsuo Yamamori RIKEN Brain Science Institute Japan Ann M Graybiel edu authors have contributed equally to this work Copyright Crittenden Lacey Weng Garrison Gibson Lin and Graybiel Crittenden Lacey Weng Garrison Gibson Lin and Graybiel This is an article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License The use distribution or reproduction in other forums is permitted provided the original or licensor are credited and that the original publication in this journal is cited in accordance with accepted academic practice No use distribution or reproduction is permitted which does not comply with these terms The striatum is key for and the motivation to move Dopamine and acetylcholine release sites are enriched in the striatum and are possibly to achieve optimal behavior Drugs of abuse which promote abnormally high dopamine release disrupt normal and drive restricted repetitive behaviors Stereotypies occur in a variety of disorders including disorder autism schizophrenia and Huntington s disease as well as in addictive states The severity of stereotypy is correlated with induction of expression in striosomes a striatal compartment that is related to the limbic system and that directly projects to neurons of the substantia nigra These characteristics of striosomes contrast with the properties of the matrix which has strong sensorimotor and associative circuit inputs and outputs Disruption of acetylcholine signaling in the striatum blocks the expression pattern induced by drugs of abuse and alters stereotypy The activity of striatal cholinergic interneurons is associated with behaviors related to sensory cues and cortical inputs to striosomes can bias in the face of conflicting cues The neurons and neuropil of striosomes and matrix neurons have observably separate distributions both at the input level in the striatum and at the output level in the substantia nigra Notably cholinergic axons readily cross compartment borders providing a potential route for local communication to maintain a balance between striosomal and matrix activity We show here by slice electrophysiology in transgenic mice that repetitive evoked firing patterns in striosomal and matrix striatal projection neurons are interrupted by optogenetic activation of cholinergic interneurons either by the addition or the deletion of spikes We demonstrate that this cholinergic modulation of projection neurons is blocked in brain slices taken from mice exposed to amphetamine and engaged in stereotypy and lacking responsiveness to salient cues Our findings support a model whereby activity in striosomes is normally under strong regulation by cholinergic interneurons favoring behavioral flexibility but that in animals with stereotypy this cholinergic signaling breaks down resulting in differential modulation of striosomal activity and an inability to bias according to relevant sensory cues striosome striatum amphetamine stereotypy cholinergic interneuron National Institute of Mental Health Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development Simons Foundation Introduction Pathologically repetitive and restricted behaviors known as stereotypies occur in numerous disorders and are notably difficult to disrupt suggesting a failure in attention to environmental cues that might normally direct a change in behavior Stereotypies can also be induced in humans and other animals by high doses of drugs such as cocaine and amphetamine Animals with stereotypic behavior exhibit high gene induction in striatal projection neurons within the striosome compartment of the striatum relative to low activation in SPNs located in the surrounding matrix compartment and Graybiel Tan et al Saka et al Crittenden and Graybiel Horner et al Jedynak et al Such differential induction in striosomes relative to induction in the matrix is blocked by intrastriatal ablation of cholinergic interneurons to herein as along with interneurons et al and manipulations of ChI signaling have a direct impact on the severity of and stereotypies et al Collins and Izenwasser Thomsen et al Aliane et al Crittenden et al drug treatments also are related to an imbalance in activity of cortical regions that differentially project to the striatal striosome or matrix compartment Kincaid and Wilson Aliane et al Friedman et al Kupferschmidt et al All together these findings suggest that a balance in activity between and ganglia loops could be critical for behavioral flexibility In contrast to the widespread interconnections that occur among the and SPNs of the direct and indirect output pathways et al SPNs that lie in the striosome or matrix compartments seem particularly separated not only physically but also electrophysiologically et al Banghart et al et al though with some crossing of their processes et al Walker et al Striosomal SPNs give rise to a unique striatonigral connection to subgroups of neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta that produce dopamine and Graybiel Fujiyama et al et al Crittenden et al a neurotransmitter that is released by all known drugs of abuse and is a key driver of motivated behaviors and movement initiation Dodson et al Howe and Dombeck Further the neurons project back both to striosomes and matrix suggesting a circuit by which striosomes could exert both localized and global control over the dorsal striatum et al For technical reasons few studies have addressed how striosomal neurons are regulated and striosomes are difficult targets because they comprise only of the SPN populations which primarily occupy the extrastriosomal matrix that houses the cells of origin of the classic direct and indirect basal ganglia pathways for motor control Yet striosomes are preferential targets of some cortical regions related to the limbic system and they target lateral circuits and the nigral pars compacta both implicated in motivation and behaviors Thus striosomal SPNs insofar as they act through their main GABAergic neurotransmitter mechanism are well placed to counterbalance of the dopamine system The relative segregation of striosomal and matrix SPNs raises the question of what mechanisms maintain the normal balance of the striatal compartments including the balanced expression of gene products such as expression that becomes in animals exhibiting stereotypy ChIs and other interneurons that are located along the striosomal borders are leading candidates for coordinating activity between the two compartments et al Sandell et al Kubota and Kawaguchi Aosaki et al Mounir and Parent Miura et al Brimblecombe and Cragg ChIs are thought to correspond to the tonically active neurons of the striatum which respond to salient or instructive stimuli with an activation pause and rebound pattern of activity et al Aosaki et al Blazquez et al Minamimoto and Kimura Goldberg and Reynolds Doig et al Thorn and Graybiel This is among TANs across the striatum and is driven by input from the neocortex and from the intralaminar nuclei of the thalamus which are themselves activated by sensory inputs et al Matsumoto et al Morris et al Brown et al Doig et al Strategic switching behaviors exhibited in learning tasks are impacted by manipulations of ChIs in the striatum et al McCool et al Brown et al Okada et al The extreme loss of behavioral flexibility that occurs in animals engaged in stereotypies is likewise modulated by cholinergic manipulations et al Collins and Izenwasser Thomsen et al Aliane et al Crittenden et al These findings suggest that thalamic and cortical input to the ChIs of the dorsal striatum helps to motor systems to modulate behavioral flexibility in the face of conflicting cues or overload of the dopamine system et al Minamimoto et al Eskow Jaunarajs et al Whether striosomal and matrix SPNs are differentially controlled by ChIs however has not been tested We now have performed such a test and have specifically asked whether we could estimate the ChIs modulation of SPN firing activity related to stereotypies by examining SPN responses in slices prepared from animals actively engaged in such behaviors It is known from much work on striatal slices that activation of ChIs induces GABA release from local sources to drive inhibitory responses in SPNs et al English et al Luo et al Nelson et al Faust et al These measurements have been made without identification of striatal compartments but likely were made mostly in the large matrix compartment Inoue and colleagues et al have now identified striosomes in a brain slice recording preparation by using young transgenic mice expressing green fluorescent protein under the control of the tyrosine hydroxylase promoter et al which is in young mice days of Paired neuronal recordings in these mice demonstrated that SPNs and other ChIs can inhibit ChIs within and across compartments et al consistent with the fact that ChI neuropil crosses compartment borders et al Crittenden et al Whether ChI activation induces the prominent pause in activity in both striosomal and matrix SPNs was not examined We performed slice recordings and optogenetic stimulation of ChIs in double transgenic mice that have GFP and channelrhodopsin in ChIs application of a blue light pulse to the slices induced a single spike in the ChIs We show here that this ChI stimulation produced a brief inhibition of evoked repetitive firing in both striosomal and matrix SPNs We also observed in SPNs of both the matrix and striosomes that the optogenetic activation of ChIs occasionally induced a in the SPN firing pattern All of these effects were blocked by the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor antagonist Furthermore in brain slices taken from transgenic mice engaged in stereotypies and to salient cues ChI stimulation failed to disrupt the evoked repetitive striosomal and matrix SPN firing These results raise the proposal favored here that the loss of behavioral flexibility that occurs in animals under the influence of psychomotor stimulants could result from a failure in the ability of ChIs to reset ongoing striatal activity and motor behavior in response to relevant environmental cues Materials and Results Mice engaged in repetitive behaviors fail to respond to a sensory cue and exhibit induction To test whether mice with stereotypies fail to respond to salient sensory cues we measured the response of male mice to the introduction of bedding from female cages to their own cage To induce stereotypy mice were treated for days with mg kg day i p followed by days of and then a challenge dose mg kg i p as previously described Crittenden et al Control mice were treated in parallel with vehicle injections only On the challenge day at min after injection we introduced a ball of used bedding taken from multiple cages of females We scored the times the mice spent sniffing the bedding locomoting or engaging in confined stereotypic behaviors based on a video taken min after the introduction of the female bedding Control mice spent between and of the time sniffing the female bedding We compared this level to the times that they interacted with bedding that had been taken from their own home cage and found that they spent significantly more time interacting with the female cage bedding supporting the interpretation that female cage bedding is a salient cue By contrast mice that were treated with repeated amphetamine spent most of their time engaging in stereotypic behaviors sometimes interrupted by running bouts and did not interact with the female cage bedding at all effect is blocked after application of Spiking in two SPNs from BAC mice that showed an advanced spike or pause response that was blocked after application of Discussion ChIs send abundant axonal projections into striosomes and matrix circuits implicated in selecting behavioral responses to salient cues Stereotypy can be viewed as an extreme loss of behavioral flexibility and loss of responsiveness to salient cues a feature recognized in individuals with disorders on the autism spectrum et al Presentation of an instructive cue induces a response in striatal ChIs consisting of a brief activation followed by a pause in spiking and then a rebound activation before a return to unsynchronized tonic firing et al Minamimoto and Kimura Goldberg and Reynolds Doig et al Thorn and Graybiel A leading hypothesis is that this ChI response is important for an animal s ability to adapt its behavior in accordance with predicted outcomes et al McCool et al Brown et al Ding et al Goldberg and Reynolds Okada et al The response of ChIs to cue presentation is dependent upon inputs from the sensory thalamus the dopaminergic system and the cerebral cortex et al Goldberg and Reynolds Doig et al Inputs from sensory thalamus to ChI dendrites are et al Raju et al Consistently we observed that ChI dendrites appeared slightly more prominent in the matrix compartment relative to the high abundance of ChI axons in both striosomes and matrix Thus ChI dendrites as well as labeling of inputs from brainstem cholinergic projections et al likely account for the overall expression of transgene reporters immunomarkers and chemical markers for cholinergic processes et al Crittenden et al Psychomotor stimulants are well known to induce stereotypic behaviors and in accordance with this linkage we found that after repeated treatment male mice were engaged in stereotypy and failed to respond when we introduced the normally salient stimulus of bedding taken from female cages Multiple brain regions and signaling mechanisms are implicated in evoking stereotypic behaviors of different sorts Mason and Rushen In the dorsal striatum dopaminergic and cholinergic signaling modulate stereotypic behaviors et al Aliane et al Crittenden and Graybiel Both increases and decreases in acetylcholine signaling have been implicated in the induction of stereotypic behavior highlighting how a balance of neurotransmitter effects may be what is key to preventing this pathological behavior For example the ablation or inhibition of ChI signaling in the anteromedial dorsal striatum prolongs stereotypy in rats et al but as well mice with abnormally high levels of VAChT thought to augment acetylcholine release exhibit increased stereotypy et al Stimulation of the ionotropic nicotinic receptors increases motoric responses to cocaine and amphetamine et al Collins and Izenwasser whereas antagonism of the slower metabotropic muscarinic signaling system generally increases responses including stereotypy et al Aliane et al Thus the relationship between cholinergic signaling and stereotypy is complex with contradictory observations being reported Some ideas that may help reconcile them are muscarinic and nicotinic transmission may in general have opposite effects disrupting cholinergic transmission in different districts of the striatum has different effects and so stereotypies may be controlled both by stimulation and by inhibition of cholinergic transmission depending on exactly where and how the stimulation or inhibition is accomplished How this relates to the role of acetylcholine in remains unknown Drugs of abuse and imbalanced striosome vs matrix gene activation With repeated administration of psychomotor stimulants overall gene induction in the matrix of the dorsal striatum is suppressed relative to control treatments and Gerfen Nguyen et al and the ratio of gene induction is increased et al Canales and Graybiel Vanderschuren et al Saka et al Jedynak et al By contrast rats engaged in normal behaviors in their home cage are reported to have similar levels of metabolic activity in the two compartments et al Experiments aimed at directly ablating striosomes in rats by intrastriatal injection of toxins et al Lawhorn et al have been reported to result in reduced stereotypic responses to methamphetamine and increased induction in the matrix et al Our experimental mice showed the expected imbalance in induction after a challenge injection of with strong nuclear immunoreactivity in neurons of striosomes and low levels of in neurons of the surrounding matrix The mice showed immunostaining that was similar across the compartments The predominant striosomal activity in animals as measured by the proxy of induction could serve to minimize excess dopamine release driven by drugs of abuse This speculation would fit with a circuit model whereby relative activation of striosomal SPNs directly inhibits neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta and relative silencing of matrix SPNs disinhibits substantia nigra reticulata neurons that thereby are released to inhibit the neurons ChI modulation of SPN spike firing patterns in striosomal and matrix SPNs The electrophysiological response of SPNs to direct ChI stimulation has been previously described without classification of striosomal or matrix cell type and thus should favor those in the matrix which makes up most of the total volume of the striatum Analyses of SPN responses to ChI stimulation have shown that there are multiple inhibitory currents with fast slow and very slow et al and small excitatory currents et al The inhibitory effects can be transmitted from ChIs to SPNs disynaptically via nicotinic release of GABA from neurogliaform and tyrosine striatal interneurons et al Luo et al Faust et al from other SPNs et al or from afferents et al Nelson et al Acetylcholine can also inhibit SPNs via muscarinic receptors on SPNs et al and via muscarinic suppression of glutamate release from cortical terminals et al The effects of ChI activation on striatal microcircuits can be particularly powerful at least as measured in slice preparations in that single spikes of ChIs can promote nicotinic release of GABA and recurrent inhibition et al Inoue et al The findings raise the possibility that the prominent pause in tonic ChI activity might in fact be preceded by a single instructive ChI action potential We found that optogenetic induction of a single spike in ChIs in striatal slices could induce both a brief pause of evoked firing activity and a spike advance in striatal SPNs Prolonged ChI stimulation appeared to have the same brief consequence on SPN firing patterns Relative to SPNs in the matrix we found that striosomal SPNs showed a greater response to ChI stimulation Considering the diversity of SPN cell types et al a larger sample of neurons would make this conclusion firmer We found that the SPN responses to ChI activation were blocked by bath application of the nicotinic receptor antagonist consistent with a disynaptic inhibition microcircuit such as that relayed by nicotinic acetylcholine receptors on GABAergic terminals All together these results suggest that there may be greater nicotinic transmission from GABAergic terminals onto at least some striosomal SPNs than onto matrix SPNs We and others previously found that subsets of nigral neurons et al and Graybiel Prensa and Parent Crittenden et al which from their positions are likely overlapping with those that synthesize GABA et al appeared to project more abundantly to striosomes than to the matrix Thus terminals from GABAergic neurons are one potential source of the increased inhibition of striosomal neurons Friedman and colleagues found that relatively selective activation of striosomal SPNs induced by optogenetic manipulation of prelimbic cortex input fibers biased rats decisions in a task so that rats were biased to choose the arm over the arm et al This effect appeared to be mediated by a microcircuit in which the activity of inhibitory interneurons of the striatum was normally enhanced by prelimbic cortical inputs during the task leading to suppression of putative striosomal SPNs but not of SPNs of the extrastriosomal matrix Our results here suggest that other microcircuits involving ChIs could be important for the relative inhibition or disruption of spike timing in striosomes It is clearly of great interest that these two classes of striatal interneurons both appear to affect SPN spike timing a fundamental characteristic of circuit organization and plasticity In some instances and in both compartments we observed an SPN spike that occurred within ms of the light application and sometimes much sooner raising the possibility of monosynaptic transmission from ChIs to SPNs Considering that evidence is sparse for nicotinic acetylcholine receptor mediated currents in SPNs et al these responses could more likely be mediated by glutamate glutamate transporters are enriched in subsets of ChIs et al Stensrud et al and glutamate released from ChIs in the dorsal striatum can induce fast excitatory responses in striatal interneurons et al Nelson et al and in SPNs et al Cholinergic signaling in the striosome and matrix compartments is disrupted in slices taken from mice engaged in stereotypy Normally electrically evoked dopamine release is slightly higher in the matrix than in striosomes and Cragg Salinas et al but in mice in which striosomal neurons are identifiable by the ratio is reversed by acute application of cocaine to the brain slices et al These findings in striatal slices suggest that cocaine disrupts local circuits that maintain the baseline ratio of dopamine signaling In brain slices from rats and mice neurokinin receptor agonists have differential effects on evoked dopamine release in the striosomes and matrix and these agonist effects are partially affected by cholinergic blockade et al Brimblecombe and Cragg Part of the effect might also be mediated by interneurons and Cragg which tend to lie near striosomal borders The possibility that striatal interneurons might mediate direct communication is further supported by the finding that striatal injection of an toxin ablates ChIs and interneurons and causes a disruption to the pattern of heightened induction in striosomes induced by dopamine agonists et al We have found that ChIs do indeed modulate of striosomal and matrix neurons in mice and that this modulation is severely blunted in slices taken from mice treated with a schedule of that induces an imbalance in the ratio of expression Repeated exposure to psychomotor stimulants strongly impacts ChI signaling in the dorsal striatum et al including partial inhibition of nicotinic acetylcholine receptor mediated dopamine release as measured by cyclic voltammetry in slices et al This effect may be a compensatory response to of the dopamine system considering that ChIs drive nicotinic acetylcholine receptor mediated dopamine release et al Cachope et al Threlfell et al Consistently application reduces electrically evoked dopamine release in both striosome and matrix compartments et al We confirmed that optogenetic stimulation induced a spike in ChIs in slices from mice but we did not examine whether baseline ChI firing rates or acetylcholine release were impaired Thus whether the signaling defects are or or both remains to be tested Regardless of the mechanism if signaling from ChIs to SPNs is important for responsiveness to salient cues one consequence of cholinergic signaling could be a loss of normal engagement with the environment When the ChI signaling across striosome and matrix compartments breaks down under drug intoxication behavioral flexibility and cue responsiveness could be lost Author contributions CL and FW conducted all recording experiments JC and CG generated mouse crosses and Frontiers Media S A fpls Plant Science Original Research Expression of Foreign Genes Demonstrates the Effectiveness of Transformation in Zea mays Yang Liyan Cui Guimei Wang Yixue Hao Yaoshan Du Jianzhong Zhang Hongmei Wang Changbiao Zhang Huanhuan Wu Sun Yi Biotechnology Research Center Shanxi Academy of Agricultural Sciences Taiyuan China College of Life Science Shanxi Normal University Genetics and Crop Plant Research Paulo Arruda University of Campinas Brazil Yi Sun com Wu edu au These authors have contributed equally to this work This article was submitted to Plant Biotechnology a section of the journal Frontiers in Plant Science Copyright Yang Cui Wang Hao Du Zhang Wang Zhang Wu and Sun Yang Cui Wang Hao Du Zhang Wang Zhang Wu and Sun This is an article distributed under the this journal is cited in accordance with accepted academic practice No use distribution or reproduction is permitted which does not comply with these terms Plant genetic transformation has arguably been the core of plant improvement in recent decades Efforts have been made to develop in planta transformation systems due to the limitations present in the methods Herein we report an improved in planta transformation system and provide the evidence of reporter gene expression in pollen tube embryos and stable transgenicity of the plants following plant transformation with optimized sonication treatment of pollen The results showed that the aeration at treatment of pollen grains in sucrose prior to sonication significantly improved the pollen viability leading to improved kernel set and transformation efficiency Scanning electron microscopy observation revealed that the removal of operculum covering pollen pore by ultrasonication might be one of the reasons for the pollen grains to become competent for transformation Evidences have shown that the eGfp gene was expressed in the pollen tube and embryos and the gene was detected in the subsequent T and T progenies suggesting the successful transfer of the foreign genes to the recipient plants The Southern blot analysis of gene in T progenies and Apr gene segregation in T seedlings confirmed the stable inheritance of the transgene The outcome illustrated that the genetic transformation system can be widely applied in the plant improvement programs with apparent advantages over transformation methods transformation sonication eGfp Zea mays Introduction Genetic transformation has become an important tool in the improvement of plants Numerous genetic transformation methods have been developed in the past three decades for a wide range of plant species Generally they have been classified into indirect or direct transformation Rao et al Biological methods using bacteria or viruses are referred to as indirect while direct methods are basically in physical ways that is by the penetration of the cell wall Torney et al Rivera et al Ziemienowicz et al At present two transformation methods are most commonly used in plants i e Agrobacterium transformation and particle bombardment Although widely used in the research community these methods have a common disadvantage i e the requirement of a long and laborious plant tissue culture process which is highly and costly Birch Ioannidis et al As some plant species or varieties are difficult to regenerate through tissue culture the applications of these methods have been restricted to some extent Furthermore the occurrence of somatic variation and low survival rate of some regenerated plantlets during transplanting process make the already low transformation efficiency further compromised Despite of some reports on transformation approaches independent of tissue culture these methods have not been applied efficiently in practice due to the complexity to operate and low efficiency Therefore transformation methods without tissue culture procedure and simple to operate are needed The interest in developing culture based or in planta transformation methods has been growing Shou et al The production of transgenic plants in such way could in general be relatively simple inexpensive and efficient Although being independent of tissue culture and having been used for many years floral dipping method is confined to only a few species that also restricted its wider application in many other plant species Clough and Bent It has been considered therefore that the reproductive system of plants is a potential pathway for the introduction of foreign genes Luo and Wu Attempts have been made to develop culture based transformation in plants in the last three decades Ohta Booy et al Li et al Pollen tube genetic transfer was reported in genetic transformation in cotton Zhou et al and rice Luo and Wu This method was once regarded advantageous due to its independency of tissue culture and plant regeneration no requirement on labs and its simplicity to operate However the transformation efficiency of this method has been proven low and thus requires massive transformant selection efforts among a large number of progenies and the method was not reproducible at least in some cases Shou et al Furthermore Booy et al demonstrated that the digestion of plasmid DNA by nuclease was a major obstacle for using pollen grains as vector for genetic transformation It has been suggested that the ultrasonication treatment of pollen grains denatures the nuclease while not completely inhibiting their viability and germination and a genetic transformation approach using plant pollen as a vector was reported Wang et al In the method pollen grains are targeted as a vector to carry foreign genes with the assistance of sonication treatments in a sucrose solution Genes of interest were then incorporated to the progenies by pollination process with the treated pollen and subsequent selection of genetically transformed seedlings transformation is a quick and easy alternative method to generate transgenic plants bypassing the requisite for tissue culture It has a potential to produce genetically modified plants within a short period leading to inclusion of the method in conventional crop breeding programs The method has also been proven applicable in sorghum Wang et al and Brassica Wang et al Nevertheless a major shortcoming of the then reported method showed low kernel setting rate after pollination because most pollen grains lose their viability after ultrasonication and fail to complete the fertilization process Further evidences of transformation in the following procedures for example during pollen germination and embryo development were lacking to support the success of transformation was due to the transformation of pollen grains Therefore improved kernel setting rate and further evidences to demonstrate the transformation of pollen grains as vectors have become desirable for wider application of such method We hypothesize that low temperature and aeration may be beneficial for maintaining pollen viability during sonication process as pollen is active in metabolisms which requires large amount of oxygen and temperature may rise Therefore we tested the effects of aeration and low temperature treatment to the sucrose solution prior to transformation of pollen grains Further we also hypothesize that foreign gene transformed to generative cell sperms will be incorporated to zygote through fertilization of egg by the sperm with transgene and then passed on to the progeny Herein we report an optimized plant transformation method that demonstrated effectiveness of the transformation of foreign genes by their expression at various stages Materials and Methods Plant Materials Maize inbred and obtained from Qiangsheng Seed Ltd Shanxi China were used throughout the study The plants were grown at an isolated experimental plot in the Experimental Research Station of Shanxi Academy of Agricultural Sciences Taiyuan China and tassels of recipient maize plants were removed before anthesis to keep a condition Pollen donor maize plants were grown in another experimental plot which was more than m apart from the recipient The seeds were sown in early May and corn ears were harvested in early October each year with sufficient irrigation when needed The field management was carried out according to the guideline provided for the breed Transformation Vectors Two constructs plasmid harboring a bar gene as a selector and a gene kindly provided by Lian et al and plasmid harboring an ampicillin resistant gene Apr as a selector and an eGfp gene gifted by Moeller et al Figure were used in the present study Plasmid DNA was extracted with alkaline lysis according to Sambrook et al FIGURE Maps of plasmids employed in the transformation the bar gene is controlled by a cauliflower mosaic virus promoter and a nos the gene is controlled by a ubiquitin promoter Z ea mays Accession No and a nos the eGfp gene is controlled by two CaMV promoters a tobacco etch virus untranslated region enhancer and a soybean vegetative storage protein terminator followed by an ampicillin Apr resistant marker gene for the selection in Escherichia coli culture Pollen Grain Treatment The Pollen Collection In order to be able to harvest desirable quality of fresh pollen old anthers were removed and the tassels were bagged in the afternoon the day prior to the collection On the collection day fresh pollen grains were collected into a paper bag between by shaking the tassels The collection was sieved to remove anthers and the pollen grains were used immediately for the downstream treatments or preserved in Petri dishes placed in a chamber at until required Aeration and Temperature Treatment Optimize for Pollen Grains A factorial design was performed to test the effect of aeration and temperature treatments on pollen viability and germination capability The factors were aeration treatment min or min and temperature or Here the group with min aeration and temperature at was regarded as an experimental control A total of g sieved pollen was suspended in ml of sterilized sucrose solution in a beaker The suspension was aerated by an air pump Figure for desired time at desired temperature as indicated previously as the treatments Approximately of the pollen suspension or equivalent to pollen grains g maize pollen Miller was allocated to a small Petri dish cm in to examine the germination rates by incubation for h at Pollen intactness and pollen tube growth were observed with an optical microscope Olympus Osaka Eight replications were taken with pollen grains for each image FIGURE Aeration treatment of sucrose solution for suspending maize pollen Sieved pollen was suspended in sterilized sucrose solution in a beaker and the suspension was aerated by an air pump for min prior to ultrasonication treatment Sonication Treatment The best combination of aeration time and temperature showing optimal pollen intactness germination rate and pollen tube growth was applied to pollen suspension before a sonication then the pollen grains were treated with an ultrasonic homogenizer Scientz Biotechnology Co Ltd China Frequency by submerging the probe of the homogenizer into the pollen suspension The power of the ultrasonic homogenizer was set to W and the sonication lasted for s each time with an interval of s for a total of six times Ten microgram of plasmid DNA W W of DNA was added to the treated pollen suspension and then sonicated again as described above All the sonication procedures were performed on ice to protect DNA and pollen contents from being degraded or damaged Untreated pollen mixed with plasmid DNA was used as control Pollination The treated pollen suspension was incubated at room temperature for min following the ultrasonication to let the pollen grains to sediment and the supernatant was then carefully discarded The pollen mass obtained was gently brushed onto the silks of recipients The pollinated ears were then bagged to protect stray pollen contamination The mature ears were harvested and the seeds were collected and stored at room temperature until they were sown in the following year Approximately one thousand maize ears were pollinated and harvested for each treatment and seed setting were recorded for each ear Transformant Screening In contrast to the transformation of somatic cells we define the primary transgenic kernels as T kernels and the seedlings from the kernels are T plants Harvested T kernels were sown in the field as described At leaf stage fresh leaves from T seedlings were collected plants pollinated with or sprayed with herbicide Basta L to select survived plants plants pollinated with plasmid DNA and total DNA was extracted with CTAB method for subsequent molecular analysis Doyle Scanning Electron Microscopy Pollen grains from sonication and control groups were fixed in glutaraldehyde solution phosphate and kept at until further processing the foreign genes were transformed through transformation method following ultrasonication treatment and expressed in the pollen tubes embryos and progenies after transformation with the optimization of the treatment by aeration for min at Male sexual reproduction system is an ideal pathway for genetic transformation In animals use of reproductive system in transgenic manipulation has been performed more than two decades ago Wagner and Hoppe and lately such gene transfer technique has been widely used in different animals including livestock Nagano et al Oatley et al In plants attempts to use pollen as a pathway for genetic transformation have been reported by Kumlehn et al and Shim et al However an efficient way for the production of transgenic plants that can be widely applied in the breeding program is needed The present study demonstrated the effectiveness of transformation elucidated the possible mechanisms underlying the transformation and presented evidences of such transformation at molecular and histological levels These suggest that the method has a potential role in plant improvement due to its merits i e bypassing tissue culture procedure simple to operate and flexible in its applications in different species and varieties Ultrasonication has been used in a few studies to treat tissues or protoplasts for easy access to the genome of recipients by foreign DNA molecules in plants Zhang et al Joersbo and Brunstedt Wang et al Zhang et al and animals Bao et al Miller et al Huber and Pfisterer Hirabayashi et al It has been proposed that ultrasonic waves produce high pressure and high temperature lead to the localized rupture of cell wall and thus enhance permeability of the plasma membrane Liu et al Wang et al They also suggested transient cavitation produced by sonication may have enhanced the entry of foreign DNA into pollen Here we demonstrated with scanning electrical microscopy that the operculum covering the pollen germination pore was removed by ultrasonication and at least in some pollen grains this made them become more competent to receive foreign DNA We observed the expression of eGfp in the major part of the pollen tube This at least indicates the transgenicity of the vegetative cell We also found that the expression of eGfp in pollen tube appeared to restrict to the tip of pollen tube where vegetative nucleus resides along with the two sperm cells We are unable to distinguish whether eGfp is expressed in the vegetative cell or the generative sperm cells or both Since the vegetative nucleus does not contribute to the zygote formation we suggest that the transmission of foreign genes such as eGfp and to T and T generations is likely through the generative sperm cells given that these cells directly contribute to the formation of the zygote Eventually the transgene is passed onto the progeny by the kernel containing embryo developed from the zygote as evidenced by the eGfp expression in T embryos and gene presence in the leaves of T plants These transformed pollen grains perform as vectors to introduce exotic genetic materials into the genome of recipient plants following pollination and fertilization of theirs eggs To the best of our knowledge this is the first direct evidence to show how sonication acts on its biological target to make it permeable to allow the uptake of DNA molecules from the surrounding solution Furthermore this also indicates that the presence of pollen pore might be the reason to enable pollen to be used as a vector to mediate genetic transformation despite its presence of protective exine wall To understand the underlying mechanisms of this transformation system more thoroughly subsequent studies are warranted to investigate the process how the foreign genes are transferred to generative sperm cells employing for instance labeling at scanning electron microscopy or TEM level what is the frequency of such transformation relative to that to vegetative cell and the possible copy numbers of genes transferred to the generative sperm cells through and genetic approaches In the present study optimal of pollen grains by aeration of min at was applied as the aeration and low temperature led to better pollen viability and kernel set We also observed that fresh pollen could be better kept with the presence of drierite Such improved pollen grain viability may have helped to some extent the introduction of foreign genes into the recipients due to higher successful pollination and thus improved kernel set during the experiment Although we used field grown plants as pollen donors in the study we observed that pollen viability can largely be maintained as long as pollen is collected in clear days according to our previous experiences over years Therefore the method is fairly robust and can be readily used by the breeders who do not have expensive greenhouse facilities Nevertheless the efficiency of the method can be improved under controlled conditions The transformation system developed by our group has been proved effective in delivering foreign genes to directly generate transgenic kernels without using tissue culture procedures The optimization of treatment conditions to pollen grains prior to sonication makes it more efficient This system has many advantages over traditional tissue transformation system i e its simplicity fast turnaround low costs so that breeders can utilize such transformation system in their breeding program without excessive efforts of training and need of expensive equipment We believe this transformation system is a promising tool and will play an important role in plant breeding area Author Contributions LY performed SEM and fluorescence microscopy observations with eGfp vision to provide a resource to help with the surge of casualties following a mass casualty incident with marrow toxic injuries Through the efforts of the National Marrow Donor Program and American Preparedness Transplant Springer Media New York specter of nuclear terrorism still threatens us all Barack Obama June address to the US Air Force Academy The Radiation Injury Treatment Network began with the ambitious vision to provide a resource to help with the surge of casualties following a mass casualty incident with marrow toxic injuries This continues to be a lofty goal that the RITN strives for but the gap between where we were following the tragedy of and today is significantly smaller The National Marrow Donor Program has had the great fortune to have a grant from the Office of Naval Research to conduct research to improve outcomes from hematopoietic transplantation As part of this grant there has been a item to conduct contingency planning in preparedness for a national disaster This effort was fulfilled for a few years then the efforts were greatly accelerated following The NMDP began by holding focus sessions with Hematology and Oncology physicians that were part of the network of transplant centers These meetings led to the close partnership with the American Society for Blood and Marrow Transplantation which broadened the audience and helped to continue to engage those who would be involved in a response These focus groups surveys and meetings culminated in the formation of the Radiation Injury Treatment Network in with the commitment of blood and bone marrow transplant units at NMDP affiliated hospitals cancer centers Hematology and oncology teams have extensive expertise in caring for patients that have been purposefully exposed to high levels of ionizing radiation in preparation for hematopoietic stem cell transplantation The resulting complications can be directly correlated to the care needed for a radiation casualty suffering from Acute Radiation Syndrome resulting from exposure to an ionizing radiation A radiological disaster could be as catastrophic as the detonation of an improvised nuclear device nuclear or a less devastating incident such as a radiological exposure device radiological source placed in a public a radiological dispersal device k a a dirty bomb where a conventional explosive spreads radiological a nuclear power plant accident or a mustard agent incident Regardless of the incident there will be casualties that require specialized supportive care to salvage their damaged hematopoietic systems From these small beginnings the group would debate the focus vision and even the name of what would become the RITN culminating in with the signing of the first contracts This was no easy task as initially the language stated the hospitals would accept patients from a radiological disaster which the hospital administration and legal staff expressed concern over After going a few rounds of review with each hospital language that was strong enough to show commitment yet flexible enough to appease the lawyers solidified The sales pitch to new institutions was a repeat of selling the pros of imagine asking a senior administrator at a hospital if they would like to join a group of hospitals preparing to receive casualties from the detonation of a nuclear device Needless to say there was some pushback However fortunately for RITN the physicians we worked with were passionate and persuasive Since those humble beginnings RITN has grown into a conglomeration of cancer treatment centers hospitals blood donor centers and cord blood banks as of late The hospitals cancer centers and the physicians that led the charge at the initial cohort of cancer centers that joined RITN should be recognized for their efforts Hospital at Washington University School of Medicine DiPersio M D Cincinnati Hospital Medical Center Davies M D City of Hope National Medical Center Nadamanee M D Partners Cancer Care RITN hospitals by location can be found at www RITN net About As stated these have grown to which can be seen in Fig location of RITN centers Fig Location of RITN centers To encourage participation we appealed to each sense of greater good as well as offered a token stipend to offset some of the costs this grant did not cover the cost of staff time fully but at least eased the sting To help with this effort the funds were provided through a fee for service agreement to reduce the restrictions on how they could be used However to ensure that we were our monies worth we began assigning annual tasks These included the development of a standard operating procedure incorporation of the RITN acute radiation syndrome treatment guidelines training conducting an exercise and testing the satellite telephone and emergency calling card Emergency Telecommunications that were issued to each center To ease this burden we developed the training and exercise so that each center could readily apply them with minimal effort We still ask each center to accomplish similar tasks each however we have added a dozen training options so that it does not get stale and broadens the perspective on impact on a local center in the event of a nuclear disaster This initiative grew to include training emergency preparedness exercises and regular workshops bringing experts together to plan and prepare for a catastrophe that everyone hopes will never happen RITN has developed and made available to the public many of the resources developed over the past years to improve preparedness including training materials disaster exercises drills materials treatment guidelines medical order sets for adult and pediatric patients and referral guidelines All of these are available on the RITN website for open use by the providing recognition is given to RITN as the source Since the RITN has assisted in the training of over medical and hospital support staff on training All of these materials are available for use and review on our public website including links to our free training MS PowerPoint slides are available to conduct training as needed to extend the effort Fig RITN training and education Since the inception of RITN exercises have been a part of the annual requirements for each hospital Each year RITN would develop a tabletop exercise where a disaster scenario would be reviewed by appropriate staff at the hospital and when appropriate with the emergency preparedness teams of the community They would then provide responses to questions on what they would have done in said situation These efforts grew to include functional exercises where portions of the response plans are acted out to exercises where mock casualties with moulage wound makeup ambulances and aircraft are mobilized for a close to realistic situation as possible All told over exercises have been coordinated or funded by RITN from to RITN does not want those who are planning an exercise to duplicate previous efforts so in addition to the after action reports from exercises explaining the lessons learned and gaps identified the full exercise planning and execution documents are posted for use on our website for general review Fig RITN exercises by year Hospitals preparing for a mass casualty incident require more than training and exercises tools are often requested and we have tried to meet these needs through the development of many resources These include the RITN ARS Treatment Guidelines RITN Hospital Referral Guidelines RITN Concept of Operations the Adult and Pediatric Medical Ordersets were developed in coordination with the Radiation Emergency Medical Management for implementation of a standard approach to patient care for those individuals who might experience an acute radiation illness RITN has come a long we still see many challenges need for continued growth of the network how to engage distant unused medical capacity through telemedicine and increasing awareness within the medical and public health community as well as many other local issues that are identified during the exercises we support However based on the great success we have seen to date we are confident that the Radiation Injury Treatment Network will continue to step up to the challenge presented mission and goals are as The Radiation Injury Treatment provides comprehensive evaluation and treatment for victims of radiation exposure or other marrow toxic injuries Many of the casualties with radiation injury will be salvageable but require outpatient and or inpatient care Recognizing this the US National Marrow Donor Program US Navy and American Society for Blood and Marrow Transplantation collaboratively developed RITN which comprises of medical centers with expertise in the management of bone marrow failure stem cell donor centers and umbilical cord blood banks across the US The goals of RITN are as follows to develop treatment guidelines for managing hematologic toxicity among victims of radiation exposure to educate health care professionals about pertinent aspects of radiation exposure management to help coordinate the medical response to radiation events and to provide comprehensive evaluation and treatment for victims at participating centers Since RITNs inception it has been fortunate to have many partners including the support of the Office of Naval Research Department of Health and Human Services Health Resources Services Administration Department of Health and Human Services Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response and the Radiation Emergency Medical Management website operated by the National Library of Medicine as well as many other prominent supporters including the National Association of County and City Health Officials Association of State and Territorial Health Officials National Alliance for Radiation Readiness European Society for Blood and Marrow Transplantation World Health Emergency Medical Preparedness and Assistance Network Radiation Emergency Assistance Center and Training Site and many others This article is part of the Topical Collection on Stem Cell Transplantation Acknowledgements
